Graphical abstract Defect engineering (endogenous sp 2 carbon-shell strategy) authorizes the generation of active sites or anchoring metals on the nanodiamond surface resulting in excellent catalytic performance. Developing innovative catalysts continues to be a pivotal interest within the heterogeneous catalysis area. The carbonaceous material ND@G, featuring a sp 2/sp 3 hybrid architecture, comprises a nanodiamond (ND) core structure encased within an ultrathin graphitic nanoshell (G), and has been widely exploited as a metal-free catalyst or a support for metal catalyst. Its unique curved zero-dimensional structure/surface and tunable defective surface characteristics endow it with outstanding performance in different heterogeneous catalytic systems. The present review summarized the construction of the diverse types of ND@G and a wide-ranging valorization of structure–activity relation with its catalytic mechanism in various reactions. The recent advancements in the impact of active sites’ architecture and the interaction between metal and support (preventing the as-formed metal species migration and agglomeration based on ND@G) on the catalytic performance of supported metal catalysts are particularly highlighted. The current challenges and outlooks/opportunities confronted by ND@G materials in catalysis are prospected by virtue of its fundamental physicochemical characterizations and potential catalytic estimation. This in-depth analysis seeks to pave the way for effective utilizing the ND@G in catalytic processes. Based on our knowledge, we also identify the challenges along with this area and offer some perspectives on how to overcome them. Among the various catalytic materials, carbonaceous substrates have garnered significant scholarly and industrial attention for their special features: high surface area, robust mechanical and chemical stability, resistance to corrosion, the capacity for electrical and thermal conduction, specific surface physiochemical properties, adjustable structure, as well as environmental acceptability (meeting the requirement of sustainable and green chemistry) [1–16]. It is widely acknowledged that metal catalysts supported by carbonaceous materials exhibit a less pronounced metal-support interaction (MSI) compared to those supported by metal oxides, which have the propensity to hinder the oxidation of the metals they support (a process that is commonly observed on the chemically reactive surfaces of metal oxide supports) [3]. Within the various carbonaceous substrates, sp 2-hybridized nanocarbons (e.g., carbon nanotubes (CNTs), fullerenes, fullerene black, graphene sheets, graphene oxides (GO), nano-onions, carbon nanofibers (CNFs), nanoflakes, etc.) have demonstrated considerable potential as catalysts or supports in various redox catalytic reactions. Functionalizing these materials with oxygen and nitrogen functionalities further enhances their ability to stabilize nanoscale metal entities, including clusters and individual atoms [17,18]. However, the surface structure and functional group alterations that carbon materials undergo during catalytic processes can lead to the instability of the supported active metals. These metal species tend to aggregate into larger metal particles, which compromises their stability [19]. A case in point is the inherent vulnerability of fuel cell systems to harsh conditions, such as elevated operating potentials and temperatures, which can degrade the sp 2-nanocarbon-based electrodes. This, in turn, results in a loss of catalytic activity due to the deactivation of Pt catalysts and the detachment of the matrix [20]. Consequently, there is a pronounced advantage in developing superior and stable carbon-based catalysts capable of withstanding harsh environmental conditions. Nanodiamonds (ND) with sp 3-hybridized structures have attracted a huge amount of attention from researchers as promising catalytic materials. ND encapsulates the unique properties of diamond, such as exceptional hardness, wear resistance, superior optical characteristics, and high thermal conductivity, alongside the inherent traits of nanomaterials, which include fine particle size, a significant surface-to-volume ratio, and elevated surface reactivity [4,21]. The detonation-derived NDs are characteristically coated with an amorphous carbon layer, which preserves inherent properties of unsaturated surface bonds, a variety of surface defects, and a surface structure that can be functionalized with diverse functional groups. The combined effect of these features imparts NDs certain catalytic activity [1,22]. Previous research has demonstrated that utilizing as-received nanodiamond (ND) powders as electrodes can significantly enhance the electrochemical activity. This enhancement is ascribed to the presence of unsaturated sp 2 bonds on the ND electrode surface, along with a broad electric potential range and a low background electric current [23,24]. Zhang et al. reported that when used as a metal-free catalyst for the direct dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (EB), as-received ND powder outperformed conventional K-promoted iron oxide and other carbon-based catalysts in terms of catalytic efficiency and stability [25]. Furthermore, the ND surface is rich in various functional groups, such as hydroxyl, carboxyl, ether, and ketone groups, which enable ND powder to serve as a support material for anchoring active metals. This support has been found to exhibit unique properties in various reactions, such as electrocatalysis, nitrobenzene reduction, and the hydrodechlorination of chlorobenzene [26]. Recently, a core-shell structure with an ND core covered by a graphitic (G) shell (ND@G) has attracted a large amount of attention [27–29]. This specific structure can be obtained through both endogenous and exogenous graphitization of the as-received ND (Fig. 1 ). The endogenous approach, which is the focus of this review, is favored for its simplicity and the ability to uniformly adjust the sp 2 structure unless otherwise indicated, all ND@G structure discussed herein are derived from endogenous processes. The endogenous synthesis sp 2 of ND@G core-shell structures, often realized through the annealing of as-received ND under an inert atmosphere or vacuum at high temperatures, involves two key processes: the graphitization of amorphous carbon and the reconfiguration of sp 3-hybridized carbon into a defective-distorted graphene sp 2-hybridized outer shell [4]. This core-shell hybrid nanostructure not only preserves the inherent properties of the ND core and graphene shell, but also features specific interface properties, which provide specific electronic structure. For example, the ND core may introduce localized electronic states that interact with the π-electron system of the graphene shell, leading to modified electronic density of states and potentially new electronic properties such as enhanced conductivity or specific energy levels for charge transfer processes. In addition, the plenty of defects on graphene shell provide active sites for catalytic reactions and anchor sites for supported metal species. All of these promote the widespread investigation of ND@G in diverse catalytic fields. Literatures have demonstrated that these endogenous core-shell sp 3@sp 2 hybrid nanostructures possess distinctive attributes, conferring them with enhanced catalytic performance in reactions compared to nanocarbons with solely sp 2 or sp 3 hybridization [20,30,31]. The existing reviews mainly summarized the applications of ND and/or ND@G in various fields, yet there remains a conspicuous absence of comprehensive studies concentrating on the intrinsic growth of endogenous ND@G, its challenges, opportunities, and recent advancements in the heterogeneous catalysis fields. In addition, the physicochemical and functional properties of ND@G are highly variable and complicated, influenced by the type of pristine ND, purification techniques, and the conditions under which they are synthesized. This variability poses significant challenges in the development of cost-effective catalysts or supports based on ND@G. While theoretical and experimental studies suggest that integrating an ND core with a sp 2-hybridized graphitic shell leads to favorable catalytic outcomes, there remains debate surrounding the specific contributions of the sp 2-sp 3 hybrid structure to the enhanced catalytic performance of supported metal catalysts. Furthermore, the contribution of ND@G in advanced carbon-based materials has not yet been thoroughly compared and explained in detail. Based on the above analysis, this comprehensive review aims to elucidate the emerging trends and advancements in employing ND@G as both a metal-free carbo-catalyst and a support for metal catalysts in various chemical reaction pathways, such as aerobic oxidation, hydrogenation, dehydrogenation, reduction, and electrochemical processes. The review commences with an overview of the fundamental properties of ND@G, which are pivotal determinants of their catalytic efficiency. Subsequently, a detailed and comparative analysis of ND@G-based catalysts is conducted, including both standalone ND@G catalysts and ND@G-supported metal catalysts, across a variety of reactions. The intrinsic microstructure of ND@G and its correlation with catalytic performance are elucidated, along with the impact of metal-support interactions in ND@G-supported metal catalysts on catalytic efficiency. Finally, the challenges and problems encountered in the application of ND@G, along with suggestions for solving these issues are proposed. We anticipate that this review will provide a comprehensive overview of the application of ND@G in heterogeneous catalysis, and inspire innovative perspectives on the utilization of ND@G in diverse catalytic applications. 2 Origin and characterization of ND@G 2.1 Endogenous graphitization of ND to ND@G ND@G is a derivative of ND, and therefore, information regarding ND is presented first. Beyond the high-energy ball milling, explosive detonation is the primary method for the large-scale synthesis of ND, accounting for approximately 75% of global production. This method is conducted by the rapid release of gases and heat, resulting in a detonated ND mixture that features a nanodiamond core encased in an outer layer of amorphous carbon interspersed with graphitic domains. This outer layer has a variety of oxygen-based functionalities, including hydroxyl, carbonyl, carboxyl, ether, and anhydride, as well as nitrogen-containing species including amines, amides, cyano, and nitro, alongside metal impurities like Fe (∼1.5 wt‰), Cr (∼0.7 wt‰), and Al (∼0.0.5 wt‰). Consequently, purification strategies, encompassing thermal and chemical processes, are essential to refine the detonated ND from soot prior to graphitization, a process that can markedly influence the composition and functional groups of the surficial coating. The synergistic application of thermal pretreatment, which involves combustion in air, and chemical procedures, utilizing inorganic acids or liquid oxidants, effectively removes surface functional groups and impurities. The resultant purified ND comprises 80%–89% carbon atoms, approximately 10% oxygen atoms, 2%–3% nitrogen atoms, 0.5%–1.5% hydrogen atoms, and trace amounts of ash. Its specific surface area spans from 100 to 500 m2 g−1, with pore volume typically around 0.84–1.27 cm3 g−1. ND@G structure can be meticulously established and regulated through thermal annealing of the pristine ND material at elevated temperatures. Drawing from literature and experimental evidence, a schematic diagram illustrating the transformation is presented in Fig. 2 . The annealing process, conducted under an inert atmosphere or vacuum at temperatures between 800–1400 °C, facilitates the reconfiguration of the ND surface structure from a combination of outer amorphous sp 2-hybridized and inner sp 3-hybridized carbon into a well-ordered, few-layer graphene-like carbon shell. The evolution from ND to ND@G can be delineated into three stages, each correlated with an increase in annealing temperature. The transformation of the ND surface into a graphitic structure typically begins at 800 °C in the inert atmosphere, along with the dissociation and removal of surface oxygen functional groups under an inert gas environment, forming one or two-layer graphene from the outer amorphous sp 2-/sp 3-hybridized carbon [32]. With the annealing temperature going up from 1100 to 1400 °C, graphitization progresses from the outer surface towards the ND core, transitioning from the ND (111) facets to graphene (001) facets, and constructing a graphitic shell consisting of five or nine layers. The graphitization depth into the diamond core is enhanced with higher annealing temperatures. Ultimately, at temperatures exceeding 1400 °C, the graphene layer continues to expand, with all sp 3 carbon of the ND core being transformed into a highly ordered sp 2 spherical curved in an onion-like carbon (OLC) structure at 1500 °C, where the sp 2 carbon content reaches 96% [4,32,33]. There is a divergence in the proposed mechanisms for the transition from sp 3 to sp 2 hybridization. Kroto et al. propose that this transition is achieved through a gradual reorganization and expansion of the bowl-like graphene structure on the ND surface [34]. In contrast, other research suggests that this phase transition is initiated by carbon defects on the ND surface, which reorganize under external conditions and evolve along the Gibbs free energy gradient of the surface, causing the formation of a graphene-like layer that curves towards the inner core, culminating in the formation of OLC [35,36]. Compared to other carbon materials, the distinctive electronic configuration of ND@G, with its π and σ bonds, facilitates the activation of valence electrons under identical reaction conditions, endowing it with higher surface energy and enhancing the generation of reactive species during catalysis. Moreover, the partial delocalization and specific defects on the ND@G surface serve as a crucial chemical interface between active sites and reaction species. When ND@G was used to support metal catalysts, the interaction between ND@G and metal species can regulate the electronic configuration of the supported metals, thereby enhancing their catalytic performance. Consequently, ND@G is advantageous for catalytic applications due to its unique sp 3-sp 2 carbon hybridization, which combines the inherent properties of the diamond core with the highly active and defective sp 2 graphitic-like shell. 2.2 Heteroatom modification into ND@G In order to further tune the physicochemical characteristics of ND@G, various heteroatoms are introduced to its surface. The introduction of heteroatoms not only facilitates the creation of acidic or basic sites but also influences the electronic configuration of ND@G, consequently altering its catalytic performance [37]. As depicted in Fig. 2, heteroatom-modified ND@G with adjustable functional groups is synthesized by doping heteroatoms, including nitrogen (N), boron (B), sulfur (S), and phosphorus (P) into the carbon transition intermediate's sp 2/sp 3 structure using precursors like NH3, H3BO3, HNO3, H2S, C12H25SO4Na, and NH4H2PO4 [38–59]. Such modified ND@G has been effectively utilized in the dehydrogenation of alkanes [38–50,60,61]. Nitrogen, with its higher electronegativity, can draw electrons from adjacent carbon atoms, enhancing their reactivity during catalysis [50,62–64]. Lin et al. elucidated the formation and dynamics of various nitrogen species within ND@G, highlighting the significance of surface oxygen groups in the nitrogen-modification process. These groups facilitate nitrogen modification through substitution reactions with nitrogen and the subsequent generation of lactam and cyano species [47]. Phosphorus modification has been reported to efficiently suppress the dissociative adsorption of oxygen during the propane’s oxidative dehydrogenation reaction. This is achieved by establishing a C–O–P covalent bond on the ND@G’s surface, which in turn curbs the excessive oxidation of the reaction products and the oxidative degradation of ND@G. As a result, this modification with P improves the selectivity and durability of the ND@G catalyst [65]. Boron doping has also been studied, providing insights into how boron interacts with the ND@G surface during the dehydrogenation reaction [66]. At low boron concentrations, boron species primarily absorb on combustion sites, reducing CO x production and enhancing propene selectivity. Xie et al. also found that boron dopant in borocarbonitirde material can reduce the nucleophilicity of the –C=O site to eliminate the CO2 emission during the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of alkanes [67]. However, when ND@G is with higher boron concentrations, tetrahedral coordinated boron can block active carbonyl groups. Sulfur, despite its inability to disrupt the symmetry of carbon’s electronic structure, has been utilized as a dopant in carbon materials. It not only increases the specific surface area but also induces high spin density and surface strain, leading to charge localization that enhances catalytic activity. Zhou et al. have reported that sulfur-doped ND@G catalysts supported on carbon nanotubes exhibited exceptional catalytic performance in ethylbenzene dehydrogenation [52,68–70]. These above-discussed characteristics of ND@G offer high chemical reactivity and significant potential for developing highly effective heterogeneous catalysts in redox reactions, surpassing the performance of sp 2 (graphene) and sp 3 (ND) carbon materials alone. The above information is concluded through several characterization techniques (see Section 2.3). To further optimize catalyst performance, it is essential to determine the optimal heteroatom content to maximize reactant conversion and desired product selectivity. Understanding the structure–activity relationship in various catalytic reactions is also a crucial parameter to investigate, as it could guide the design of catalysts aimed at improving activity and selectivity. 2.3 Characterization of ND@G Thorough and precise characterization of catalytic materials is essential for the development of high-performance catalysts. In this section, we systematically consolidate the characterization studies utilizing a suite of analytical techniques to delineate the physicochemical properties of ND@G, consisting of microstructure and surface chemistry [4,71–73]. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) has been utilized to reveal the morphology and microstructure of ND@G (Fig. 3 a), where particles synthesized at elevated temperatures (>800 °C) exhibit a well-ordered diamond core with (111) planes enveloped by an irregular graphitic carbon shell. The curvature of defective graphene layers is attributed to their interaction with the ND substrates. The number of sp 2 graphene layers in the outside graphitic shell, with an interplanar distance of 0.34 nm, varies with the annealing temperature, ranging from 800 to 1500 °C [32]. Electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) (Fig. 3b) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Fig. 3c) [4] analysis provides further evidence of the graphitization process. As the annealing temperature increases, the EELS peak centering at 285 eV (corresponding to 1s → π* transitions in sp 2 carbon) strengthens, and the peak centering at 292 eV (associated with 1s → σ* transitions in sp 3 carbon) diminishes, indicating the transformation of the outer sp 3 layer into an sp 2 graphene shell. The XRD pattern of ND@G displays a pronounced peak centering at 25.3°, characteristic of graphitic (002) planes, alongside peaks centering at 43.9°, 75.4°, and 91.9°, corresponding to diamond (111), (220), and (311) planes, respectively, signifying the transition from sp 3 to sp 2 carbon. UV-Raman spectroscopy technique, known for its acute sensitivity to the surface carbon bonding configurations (Fig. 3d), was also employed to assess the evolution of graphitic layers of ND@G. With increasing annealing temperature, the diamond peak centering at 1324 cm−1 weakens, and the peak centering at 1635 cm−1 shifts towards the G band, indicating the transformation of disordered/amorphous carbon into well-ordered sp 2-bonded graphite carbon and the elimination of hydroxyl and carbonyl groups. The D band at 1400 cm−1, associated with disorder-induced defects, appears due to defective carbon sites. The graphitic lattice of ND@G exhibits a variety of structural deviations from the ideal hexagonal motif, including dangling bonds, vacancies, curved hexagons, bridges, pentagon-heptagon pairs, edges, heteroatom dopants, and oxygen functional groups, which would disappear at higher temperatures [74]. These features, varying in size and defect concentration, collectively define the surface characteristics of ND@G material. The characterization analysis presented herein uniformly demonstrates that the annealing process induces a restructuring of the amorphous carbon with mixed sp 2 -sp 3 bonding in the outer shell into a predominantly well-ordered sp 2 bonded carbon, establishing a robust foundation for subsequent catalytic applications. During the annealing process, the transition of nanocarbon hybridization from sp 3 to sp 2 is accompanied by a substantial modification of the surface oxygen-containing groups on ND@G. This phenomenon is crucial for its applications and has been elucidated through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Diffuse reflection Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFT) (Fig. 3e and f). Initially, ND@G possesses approximately 9.8% of surface oxygen-containing functional groups, which are primarily attributed to carbonyl groups (C=O, identified at 531.8 eV in XPS and 1788 cm−1 in DRIFT spectra), ether-like single bonds (C–O, at 532.8 eV and 1052–1328 cm−1), and phenolic groups (–OH, at 533.7 eV and 1400 cm−1). Post-annealing, there is a marked reduction in the oxygen species concentration of ND@G (from 9.8 at% to 0.5 at%), with the C=O peak wavenumber downshifting to 1728 cm−1, indicative of carbonyl ketones stretching modes, and the appearing of a new signal at 1580 cm−1, characteristic of aromatic C=C stretching modes. Temperature-programmed desorption of carbon monoxide (TPD-CO) profiles indicates that the thermal transformation of ND initiates with the release of H2O and the desorption of surface oxygen-based groups from the surface of sp 3-hybridized ND at approximately 200 °C (Fig. 3g). Subsequent temperature elevating to 700 °C, various functional groups on the ND surface are efficiently eliminated. This includes carboxyl groups (–COOH) at approximately 450 °C, anhydride groups (O=C–O–C=O) at around 550 °C, ether groups (C–O–C) at about 650 °C, and phenol groups (C–OH) at around 700 °C. This process is accompanied by the release of carbon monoxide (CO) and carbon dioxide (CO2) gases, as illustrated in Fig. 3g. At annealing temperatures surpassing 800 °C, only surface C=O groups persist, signifying that the highly defective graphene-like shell/surface can accommodate a certain quantity of ketone-type groups. This retention of surface C=O groups underscores the capacity of the defective graphene-like structure to harbor specific functional groups, which is instrumental for the subsequent catalytic applications of ND@G. The aforementioned findings indicate that hydroxyl, carboxylic, and anhydride groups on ND@G are susceptible to thermal degradation and can be readily eliminated through the annealing process. Whereas the ketone groups exhibit enhanced thermal stability and are selectively preserved on the ND@G surface. The ketone and diketone carbonyl groups, characterized by their high electron density around the oxygen atoms, act as Lewis bases. These groups can effectively activate saturated hydrocarbons through electron donation, thereby serving as catalytic active sites for the hydrogenation of saturated hydrocarbons [3,25,76–78]. When the ND@G supports the metal catalysts, such surface functionalities not only enhance the adhesion of active metal sites without the need for stabilizers but also augment the hydrophilicity of the catalyst, ensuring a uniform metal species dispersion. It is widely documented that an optimal annealing temperature for ND@G in catalytic applications is within the range of 900–1100 °C, a temperature that favors the development a few of graphene layers in the graphitic shell while retaining the reactive oxygen functional groups (ketone and diketone carbonyl groups), alongside an ND core [47,72,79]. Furthermore, the doping with heteroatoms like N, B, and P into ND@G has been shown to enhance catalytic activity, particularly in electro- and photo-catalytic reactions (Fig. 3h). In some instances, these modified catalysts outperform traditional metal-based catalysts [80]. The optimal content of heteroatoms enables the heteroatom-doped ND@G materials with metallic conductivity. Boron-doped ND@G, in particular, demonstrates exceptional conductivity alongside low background current, high mechanical and electrochemical stability, and resistance to fouling and corrosion [47,81–87]. The integration of frustrated Lewis acid-base pairs within the carbon framework of ND@G has been investigated for their catalytic applications. For example, nitrogen, which is electron-rich, and boron, which is electron-poor, have been immobilized onto the graphitic sheets of ND@G through the use of ionic liquids that incorporate these elements. This process was concluded with a heat treatment at 600 °C to secure the elements in place [75]. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis verified the incorporation of boron, nitrogen, and carbon atoms within the ND@G layer structure, as depicted in Fig. 3h. Importantly, oxygen-containing functional groups in ND@G play a pivotal role in determining the final distribution and loading of heteroatoms. While nitrogen-doped ND is formed during detonation synthesis due to the use of nitrogen-containing explosives, its effectiveness as a dopant in ND@G is limited. This may be due to nitrogen atoms being preferentially located within the ND core, which is inaccessible to reagents, and thus, it does not contribute to the surface chemistry of ND@G. The potential disordered carbon shells and abundant surface oxygen-terminated structures provide reactive sites for catalytic activity. 3 Catalytic application 3.1 ND@G as metal-free catalysts Owing to its unique sp 3-sp 2 carbon hybridization, the defective graphitic shell, and the distinctive tunability in physicochemical properties (as detailed in Section 2.3), the ND@G material represents a novel frontier in the development of metal-free catalysts (carbocatalysts) in various catalytic processes. Importantly, as a metal-free catalyst, it eliminates the complexity associated with multivalent metal sites, thereby streamlining the investigation of its catalytic mechanisms. This part provides a comprehensive overview of a variety of reactions catalyzed by ND@G metal-free catalysts, encompassing dehydrogenation, selective oxidation, electrocatalysis, and the detoxification of organic pollutants, with a particular focus on unraveling the roles and functions of ND@G. 3.1.1 Dehydrogenation reaction Zhang et al. first demonstrated the effectiveness of ND@G for the steam-free direct dehydrogenation (DDH) of ethylbenzene (EB) into styrene (ST) [25]. Initially, the pristine NDs were applied as the catalyst to catalyze the DDH of EB (Reaction conditions: 0.05 g catalyst, 550 °C, 2.8% EB in He, total flow rate 10 mL min−1), which achieved remarkable catalytic performance, converting 20.5% of EB with 97% selectivity towards ST. This performance surpasses that of commercial K-Fe catalysts by nearly threefold in steady-state activity (Fig. 4 a). As shown in Fig. 4b, the NDs also exhibited superior activity when compared with other carbon materials (carbon nanotubes (CNTs), nanographite, activated carbon (AC), mesoporous carbon). Moreover, this catalyst displays remarkable stability over a long period of time (60 h), as shown in Fig. 4a. Ba et al. also found that NDs showed superior catalytic performance than other carbon materials (graphite oxide, few-layer graphene, CNTs) and industrial K–Fe catalyst (Reaction conditions: 550 °C, 2.8% EB in helium, 30 mLmin−1) [88]. The authors found that the NDs were in situ transformed into ND@G at 550 °C under the reaction conditions, and the ND@G structure contributed to the remarkable catalytic activity and selectivity [25]. The enhanced activity of ND@G is attributed to its ordered sp 2- and sp 3-hybridized carbon structure, which provides surface groups and defect sites that facilitate EB dehydrogenation to ST and enable it to withstand harsh conditions due to its high oxidative resistance. The presence of ketonic groups (C=O) on graphitic overlayers, acting as electron donors, likely activates the alkane chain of EB, leading to ST formation. Concurrently, an intermediate hydroxyl group (C–OH) moiety on ND@G is generated, which interconverts with C=O during the catalytic process. DFT calculations revealed that defective sites in the curved graphene sheets are highly active for this reaction, with edges predominantly saturated with O and/or H atoms. The morphological features of ND@G, including graphene layers, shell curvature, and spatial arrangement, positively influence the dehydrogenation process [25]. The partial delocalization of π-electron density and the blend curvature of the sp 2 graphitic shell may contribute to the superior activity, favoring the desorption of products and formation of H2 from hydroxyl groups. The spatial arrangement of ND@G also offers good access to reactants or substrates. Additionally, the excellent thermal conductivity of the sp 3 ND core could enhance heat transfer near the active sites. However, the thermal cleavage of ketonic groups from graphene layers and the effect of H2 passivation lead to a decline in C=O active site concentration, resulting in reduced ND@G catalyst activity. In another work, Wang et al. compared the catalytic performance of various ND@G materials, which were obtained through annealing pristine NDs in He flows at varying temperatures ranging from 550 to 1300 °C, in the DDH of propane. The DDH reaction was conducted at 550 °C (Reaction conditions: 250 mg catalyst, 2% propane in He, 15 mL min−1) [4]. A compilation of the steady-state conversion rates and propene yield/selectivity after 8 h of reaction for the various ND@G materials was summarized in Table S1. It was found that ND@G obtained at an annealing temperature of 1000 and 1100 °C demonstrated notably higher catalytic efficiency, achieving a propene yield of 9.63% and 10.1%, respectively, significantly surpassing that of other catalysts, such as untreated ND (3.2%) and carbon nanotubes (0.7%), and ND@G obtained at other annealing temperatures (Fig. 4c) [4]. This result demonstrates that the ND@G obtained at 1000–1100 °C exhibits an optimal sp 3-sp 2 hybridized core-shell structure and the highest density of defect sites, which acts as an appropriate matrix for the formation of ketone groups and exhibits superior catalytic activity. However, when the annealing temperature surpassed 1100 °C, a decrease in catalytic activity was noted, likely due to the formation of onion-like carbon (OLC) at higher temperatures (>1300 °C), which led to a reduction in defect sites. The pristine ND and ND@G materials obtained at annealing temperatures from 1000 to 2000 °C in He flow are also applied to catalyze the decomposition dehydrogenation of methane (Reaction conditions: 150 mg catalyst, 850 °C, 10% CH4 in N2, 50 mL min−1) [73]. As shown in Fig. 4d, the pristine ND showed higher catalytic activity than CNTs, and AC catalysts, both at the initial stage and after 8 h of reaction. The inset in Fig. 4d displayed that the pristine ND exhibited the highest initial catalytic activity. However, it was observed that this catalyst experienced the fastest deactivation rate. The ND@G obtained at higher temperatures showed lower initial catalytic activity but a more stable performance over a long period of time. The researchers proposed that the superior catalytic activity is primarily attributed to the defective sites within the sp 2 graphene matrix rather than surface oxygen atoms, and the thermal annealing at high temperatures improves the ordering of surface atoms, leading to a more stable performance over a long period of time but a reduced catalytic activity. It is noteworthy that the DDH of alkanes is impeded by high energy demands, which often result in carbon deposits and catalyst deactivation. In contrast, oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of alkanes, an exothermic process with lower energy requirements, has emerged as a promising alternative. However, achieving high selectivity in ODH remains challenging due to undesired side reactions, such as the formation of CO x . Metal-free nanocarbon catalysts have been extensively investigated for ODH reaction of various hydrocarbon substrates, including ethane, propane, butane, and ethylbenzene [50,90–95], with ND@G being one of the materials reported [65,66,96–105]. The exceptional graphitization of ND@G's shell endows it with remarkable adaptability to withstand severe operational conditions, particularly in terms of oxidative resistance. Through a systematic increase in annealing temperatures from 1000 to 1500 °C, various ND@G materials were synthesized to probe the structural implications of the transformation and chemical characteristics of surface oxygen groups in ODH reactions [89]. As shown in Fig. 4e and f, the surface ketonic carbonyl groups generally play a key role in the ODH reaction. However, the pristine ND exhibited a lower activity than ND-1000 (obtained by annealing pristine ND at 1100 °C), although it had the maximum amount of ketones. This means that the catalytic activity of ODH was not simply determined by the content of active ketone groups. It was found that the active oxygen species can be generated in situ by the chemisorption of O2. A significantly increased ratio of CO/CO2 with the increasing of annealing temperature of ND@G suggests that the ketone groups were formed preferentially on the defects of catalysts annealed at a higher temperature in the ODH reaction. Moreover, it was found that with the increase in the annealing temperature, the consumption rate of propane catalyzed by a single ketone increased gradually. This indicates that the sp 2-hybridized structure could also promote the activity of the ketone groups. The propane ODH was also conducted over ND@G-1000 material that was incipient-wetness impregnated with varying quantities of boron or phosphorus heteroatoms (Reaction conditions: 450 °C, catalyst weight 150–180 mg, C3H8/O2/He = 1/1/31.3.) [65,66]. It was found that the adsorption of borate or phosphate on the ND@G surface led to a decrease in both product formation rates (propene and CO x ) and reactant conversion rates overall modified ND@G catalysts, attributed to the blockage of combustion sites and active/defect species (Fig. 4g and h). However, heteroatom modification was confirmed to enhance alkene selectivity in ODH reactions compared to pristine ND@G when the modified ND@G is with proper content of the heteroatom species (Fig. 4g and h). The authors propose that a proper concentration of heteroatom species could selectively interact with specific preferred sites on the surface, rather than blanketing it, which explains the concurrent increase in propene selectivity. Importantly, it was found from the temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) analysis that after phosphate modification, the ND@G sample showed a high oxidative stability at 500 °C. Therefore, in a long-term ODH reaction performed at 500 °C, the phosphate-modified catalyst provided a stable catalytic performance for a time on stream of 20 h. These findings offer novel perspectives on the interaction mechanisms between heteroatoms and the carbon surface, as well as their impact on catalytic behavior in ODH reactions, potentially guiding the rational modification of nanocarbons for enhanced catalytic performance. 3.1.2 Selective oxidation reaction In addition to dehydrogenation reactions, ND@G has also served as a metal-free catalyst for selective oxidation reactions (SOR), where it serves as a metal-free catalyst for the oxidation of a wide variety of alcohols into aldehydes [71]. Lin et al. compared various ND@G materials, which were obtained at different annealing temperatures, for the SOR of alcohols. The reaction conditions as well as the data regarding the activity and selectivity are summarized in Table S1 and are also displayed in Fig. 5 (a). Here, the t-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP) was used as an oxidant. It can be found that ND@G-1300 (obtained by annealing pristine ND at 1300 °C), displayed the highest catalytic activity among the various metal-free catalysts used here. And the catalytic activity and aldehyde selectivity of ND@G-1300 is comparable to that of noble-metal catalysts, e.g., Pt/C and Ru/C (Fig. 5a) [71]. Moreover, it was reported that ND@G-1300 demonstrated good stability during recycling. After six successive runs, the conversion of alcohol and the corresponding aldehyde selectivity showed no significant decrease. The authors elucidated the activation mechanism of ND@G, finding that the edge defects with a zigzag configuration play an important role in the catalytic process, based on the excellent decomposition capability of TBHP and the effective activation of the alcohol substrate, as elucidated by the model catalysts, the ex-situ electrochemical, and the ex situ attenuated total reflectance studies. It was revealed that the surface oxygen groups do not have a key role in the reaction. These findings contrast with the conventional belief in the predominant function of surface oxygen groups. In another research, the selective oxidation of 2,3,6-trimethylphenol was examined with a range of ND@G materials obtained at annealing temperatures ranging from 900 to 1300 °C [32]. It was found that the catalytic activity showed a strong positive correlation with the electronic properties of ND@G, specifically its work function (Fig. 5b). The specific π and σ electronic structures and the lower work functions of ND@G probably induced by their high curvatures inevitably endow them with a higher surface energy that may be beneficial to improve the catalytic activity. These insights highlight the critical influence of electronic properties in governing the catalytic efficiency of ND@G in selective oxidation reactions, providing new perspectives for optimizing ND@G-based catalysts to improve both activity and selectivity. 3.1.3 Acetylene hydrochlorination and nitro compounds reduction The reduction reactions, such as the nitro compounds reduction and the acetylene hydrochlorination, are also critical processes with a wide range of applications. Lin et al. applied ND@G materials obtained at annealing temperatures ranging from 900 to 1300 °C to catalyze the hydrogenation reduction of nitrobenzene at 100 °C, and N2H4 was used as the reductant. The catalytic performances of the various ND@G materials are displayed in Table S1 and Fig. 5(c). It can be found that the catalytic activity increased with the increasing annealing temperature. The authors attributed this to the effect of the electronic properties of ND@G, specifically the surface work function of ND@G. The ND@G obtained at a higher annealing temperature has a lower surface work function. And the lower the work function, the higher the surface activity, which could promote the reduction of nitrobenzene. A recent breakthrough by Zhang et al. explored the catalytic hydrogenation reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol using ND@G catalysts synthesized by annealing pristine ND at temperatures ranging from 600 to 1100 °C [106]. It was also found that the catalytic activity increased with the increase in annealing temperature, with ND@G-1100 showing nearly complete conversion, outperforming those of ND@G catalysts treated at lower temperatures (Fig. 6 a and b). Analysis indicated a positive correlation between the content of graphene-like shells and catalytic efficiency. Conversely, acidic oxygen-containing groups were found to adversely affect catalytic activity, possibly by impeding the adsorption of 4-nitrophenol anions due to electrostatic repulsion in an alkaline reaction medium. The reusability of the ND-1100 catalyst in the catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol was further investigated based on its excellent activity. It was reported that no obvious decrease is observed in the conversion of 4-NP after five consecutive uses, indicating the ND-1100 catalyst owns excellent reusability. The ND@G obtained at annealing temperature of 900 °C was also applied to catalyze the hydrochlorination of acetylene at 220 °C, with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of C2H2 = 30 h−1 [107]. As shown in Fig. 6c and Table S1, the ND@G exhibits exceptional catalytic performance, with a conversion reaching 50.12% and selectivity for chloroethylene exceeding 99.5%, which is similar to that of 0.25% AuCl3/AC, but markedly outperforms the AC, N-doped mesoporous carbons (N-MCs), 1% Ru/AC, and widely used HgCl2/AC catalyst under the same conditions. The researchers suggested that the enhanced catalytic performance of ND@G in the hydrochlorination of acetylene may be due to the defect sites on its surface. These sites facilitate the creation of unsaturated bonds at the periphery of the sp 2 carbon domains, disrupting electron-hole symmetry and boosting the adsorptive capacity for reactants like C2H2 and HCl. More importantly, ND@G was then tested for acetylene hydrochlorination at 220 °C, 30 h−1 for 200 h, and compared with the commercial activated carbon, as displayed in Fig. 6c. It is evident that ND@G showed no loss in activity during the 200 h-reaction, indicating its remarkable stability for the hydrochlorination of acetylene. 3.1.4 Organic pollutants decomposition The increasing environmental degradation has spurred global research efforts in developing green and efficient remediation strategies, aiming to achieve sustainable development for human society. As green technologies, advanced oxidative processes (AOPs) have been extensively employed for the decomposition of toxic organic pollutants in wastewater into harmless mineral acids,CO2, and water, using varioussuperoxides (e.g., H2O2, peroxysulfate salts, etc.)to generate reactive oxygen species, such as sulfate radicals (SO4 −•)andhydroxyl radicals (•OH). Numerous studies have reported that ND@G can effectively activate peroxysulfate salts, generating highly reactive radicals that facilitate the oxidative decomposition of toxic organic pollutants in wastewater [108–112]. Duan et al. carried out an in-depth study on the non-metallic catalytic performance of ND@G in the activation of persulfate to decomposing phenol in water at room temperature [108]. According to the results of electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), it was found that the ND@G is capable of activating persulfate, leading to the production of SO4 −• and •OH. The catalytic activity was observed to increase proportionally with the temperature at which the ND@G was annealed. The ND@G-1000 demonstrated superior catalytic efficiency, with complete removal achieved within 30 min. While the pristine ND showed poor activity. This indicates that the graphiticshell structureof ND@G-1000 functionalized with thesurface defectscan effectively interact with PS for activation of O–O bond and generation of reactive species. This process begins with the oxidation of water molecules on the ND@G surface, where intermediates that have been oxidized are essential for the activation of persulfate (Fig. 7 a). Moreover, ND@G-1000 demonstrated superior pollutant decomposition efficiency compared to conventional metal-based catalysts such as Fe ions, CuO, Co3O4, and Ga2O3, which showed the potential application of ND@G material in the decomposition of organic pollutants. In another study by Shao et al., the ketonic carbonyl groups, which act as Lewis basic sites on the ND@G surface, were identified as the catalytically active sites for persulfate activation [112]. By adjusting the thermal annealing temperature between 550 and 800 °C, they altered the concentration of C=O groups. This adjustment led to the discovery of a relationship, both semi-quantitative and quantitative, linking the ketonic carbonyl groups to the reaction rate constants. It suggested that these ketonic groups serve as active sites for the decomposition of persulfate into singlet-oxygen (1O2), which outperforms conventional radicals in efficiently oxidizing and mineralizing target contaminants. Most intriguingly, in their another work, Duan et al. reported that ND@G exhibited the ability to catalyze a nonradical oxidation process, marking a new pathway that deviates from the conventional radical-based mechanisms [109]. They found that both radical and nonradical oxidations are very pronounced in the ND@G/peroxymonosulfate (PMS)system. Through experiments utilizing radical scavengers, they verified that the defective edges within ND@G, especially those with zigzag or armchair structures, are capable of facilitating oxidation reactions without the need for free radical production. These edges, with their unique electronic and chemical properties, enable the activation of PMS by localizing the delocalized π system, thus facilitating electron transfer and bond cleavage without producing free radicals (Fig. 7b and c) [111]. Lee et al. also documented similar observations, noting that the degradation kinetics were unaffected by the presence of oxidant scavengers and natural organic matter [110]. This suggests that radical intermediates do not play a predominant role in the persulfate-induced oxidation of organic substances. Results from linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) analysis, Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, and EPR spectroscopy indicate the readily binding of persulfate and phenol to the ND@G surface, potentially forming a charge transfer complex. In this complex, ND@G is pivotal in facilitating efficient electron transfer from phenol to persulfate. Furthermore, the authors compared the catalytic efficiency of ND@G with other carbon materials featuring sp 2 graphitic structures, such as CNTs, C60, and graphite, and found that phenol removal was most rapid with ND@G [110]. Duan et al. further explored the activation mechanisms of PMS over ND@G catalysts, revealing that the pathway depends on the content of the sp 2 graphitic layers in ND@G [108]. As the number of graphitic layers increases from one in ND@G-900 to 4–6 layers in ND@G-1100, there is a shift from a radical-mediated reaction that generates producing sulfate radicals and hydroxyl radicals to a nonradical oxidation pathway (Fig. 7b). This dual capability, both for radical and nonradical oxidation, provides new insights into the catalytic behavior of ND@G and opens up possibilities for developing advanced oxidation technologies that can operate through multiple reaction pathways. 3.1.5 Electrochemical reaction Although noble-metal-based cathode catalysts show commendable performance in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) for fuel cell energy generation, their broader use is limited due to the rarity of these metals, high expenses, and their vulnerability to performance decline and deactivation caused by methanol from the anode crossing over and CO poisoning. Consequently, there is a growing interest in catalysts that are either metal-free or made from non-precious metals, which are seen as potential alternatives for large-scale fuel cell applications [113–121]. Developing metal-free carbon nanomaterial catalysts for electrochemical processes has long been a formidable challenge. However, recent advances in nanocarbon technology have led to notable improvements in electrocatalytic performance. ND@G and its related derivatives have emerged as cost-effective electrode materials, characterized by their unique structure, electronic conductivity, diverse structural configurations, customizable surface chemistry—featuring oxygenated active groups and a spectrum of defects—and robust stability. In contrast to conventional nanocarbon materials, ND@G provides a plethora of active sites and can be precisely manipulated to enhance both reaction kinetics and mass transport in electrochemical processes. The adjustable features of ND@G render it a viable candidate for boosting the rate and diffusion of electrochemical reactions. Such properties could surpass the restrictions of conventional catalysts, potentially leading to the development of higher-performance and eco-friendly fuel cell systems. Kannari et al. evaluated the performance of ND@G catalysts, synthesized at temperatures between 1000 and 2000 °C in ORR [124]. Their research revealed a significant link between the ORR performance and the catalysts' defect content. Specifically, ND@G synthesized at 1400 °C exhibited enhanced activity, attributed to the development of curved, graphitic structures with edge defects, which are advantageous for oxygen adsorption and reduction. Doping carbon materials with heteroatoms such as N, B, S, and P has also attracted considerable attention, as it can modify the electron-donor properties of carbon, significantly boosting the ORR performance of ND@G. The incorporation of the heteroatoms can modulate the electron-donor characteristics of carbon materials, thereby significantly boosting their catalytic performance in ORR, potentially matching the activity and durability of platinum (Pt). Zhu et al. fabricated nitrogen-doped ND@G with a variable sp 2 /sp 3 carbon ratio, controlled by the annealing temperature, to enhance ORR activity and stability [48]. They demonstrated that as the sp 2 carbon content increased, the ND@G catalyst exhibited improved ORR performance. The researchers also found that nitrogen species, especially pyridinic nitrogen, play a crucial role in stabilizing N-doped ND@G (N/ND@G) during electrochemical cycling, leading to enhanced stability. Dong et al. prepared N/ND@G by employing a post-doping treatment that involved heating a mixture of oxidized ND@G (synthesized at 1400 °C) and melamine at 1000 °C, as depicted in Fig. 8 a and b [122]. This approach yielded a catalyst also with enhanced properties, showcasing the potential of N/ND@G in electrochemical applications. N/ND@G exhibited electrocatalytic performance for the four-electron ORR that is on par with Pt-based catalysts, featuring a similar mechanism for oxygen adsorption and activation. The core-shell structure of ND@G reduces the tendency to stack which is common in traditional N-doped graphene, thereby boosting its catalytic effectiveness. The cooperative effect among graphitic-N, pyridinic-N, and pyrrolic-N in N/ND@G leads to a catalyst with significantly higher electrocatalytic activity than un-doped ND@G, while retaining the exceptional electrochemical stability of ND@G. This renders N/ND@G a highly effective and stable candidate for cathode catalysts in fuel cell applications. Apart from doping with single-heteroatom, the simultaneous introduction of various heteroatoms into ND@G, known as co-doping, has been identified as a potent approach to improve catalytic performance. The co-doping not only generates extra catalytic sites, but also fine-tunes the physicochemical characteristics, such as electronic properties and surface chemistry. Liu et al. synthesized a material of boron and nitrogen co-doped ND@G, designated as BN/ND@G, using a simple one-step thermal treatment with a combination of nanodiamond, melamine, boric acid, and FeCl3 [123]. This BN/ND@G catalyst showed superior electrocatalytic activity and durability in alkaline conditions for the ORR, surpassing the performance of materials doped with only boron or nitrogen (B/ND@G and N/ND@G) (Fig. 8c and d). The distinctive core-shell configuration of ND@G, coupled with the effects of boron and nitrogen co-doping, contributes to the catalyst's exceptional performance. According to the analysis of the application of ND@G in various catalytic reactions, the extraordinary catalytic performance of ND@G can be attributed to a number of key factors: (i) the specific hydrid structure of ND@G features sp 3-C at its core and sp 2-C forming the outer graphitic shell; (ii) the electron-donating ketonic groups as well as various defects on the graphitic layers, which boost activity; (iii) the curvature of the graphene layers, which enhances activity by partially delocalizing π-electron density; and (iv) The round shape of ND@G could potentially make it easier for reactants to reach the active sites and engage with the π-conjugated system. Moreover, due to its superior catalytic performance for the decomposition of organic pollutants and the electrochemical reaction (e.g., ORR) compared to other carbon-based metal-free catalysts and even commercial metal-based catalysts, the ND@G material displayed great potential for environmental protection and energy conversion Despite the ongoing challenges in developing ND@G catalysts that consistently exhibit high activity and stability across various reactions, these state-of-the-art ND@G catalysts have attracted considerable interest. This is attributed to their unique structure and physicochemical characteristics. The advancements in this area hold great prospects for the development of highly efficient carbon-based catalysts that do not rely on metal components. 3.2 ND@G as the metal catalysts support Due to its unique physicochemical characteristics, ND@G distinguishes itself as a metal-free carbocatalyst and also serves as an innovative support material for the preparation of metal-containing catalysts [33,125–130]. The presence of abundant defect sites, functional groups, and substantial specific surface area makes ND@G particularly effective in stabilizing atomically dispersed metal species (ADMs), which include single atoms (SAs) and small clusters [131,132]. The propensity of ADMs to deactivate due to high surface free energy is significantly reduced when they are supported on ND@G. Empirical studies have shown that the physicochemical properties of the ND@G support, including its surface defects and functional groups, significantly influence metal-support interactions as well as the dispersion of the supported metal species, different from those observed with conventional carbon-based supports [127,133–138]. Importantly, these studies also demonstrate that manipulating the interaction between metal and the support can regulate the catalytic performance of metal species supported on ND@G, including their activity, selectivity, and stability. Additionally, the catalytic performance of metal species—SAs, clusters, or nanoparticles (NPs)—can vary significantly based on factors such as size, structure, and coordination configuration. These differences impact the activation capabilities and the dynamics of adsorption/desorption on substrates or intermediates, leading to variations in catalyst activity and selectivity across different reactions [127,139,140]. Single-atom catalysts, which utilize the full potential of metal atoms and feature unique electronic configurations, are characterized by isolated metal atoms anchored to unsaturated coordination sites, such as heteroatoms and ligands. This configuration can lead to novel reaction pathways, leading to exceptional activity and selectivity [141,142]. Metal clusters, composed of a finite number of metallic atoms or multi-metallic atoms, are predominantly located on the ND@G surface, fully exposed and engaged in the catalytic reaction, with each atom playing a critical role. The bonds between metals in these clusters are crucial for effectively absorbing and activating reactants in targeted catalytic processes. Slight changes in the structure or chemical makeup, like the introduction or loss of an atom or electron, can significantly impact the catalysts' activity and selectivity. In this discourse, an overview of the preparation techniques for ND@G-supported catalysts is initially presented. Subsequently, a comprehensive summary of the applications of ND@G-supported catalysts in diverse catalytic reactions is provided, organized by metal type and reaction category. The selected examples predominantly highlight the superior performance of ND@G compared to conventional supports, offering insights into the factors that contribute to its enhanced performance. 3.2.1 Synthesis of ND@G supported catalyst A multitude of techniques have been implemented for the fabrication of supported catalysts, with the choice of method being contingent upon the specific performance demands and characteristics of the targeted catalytic reaction. Among these, ND@G-based catalysts have garnered significant attention. Beyond the traditional utilization of metal nanoparticles (MNPs), it has been extensively documented that ND@G can serve as a support for metal catalysts, enabling the formation of atomically dispersed metals (ADMs) with controlled dimensions and morphology. This capability stems from the presence of surface defective graphene-like layers in ND@G that possess unpaired bonds. These bonds could facilitate the dispersion of metal centers, thereby maximizing catalytically active surface area, which is essential for the adsorption and activation of reactants, the facilitation of reaction kinetics, as well as the desorption of products. The uniformity of metal centers within the catalyst is directly related to their selectivity [2]. In this section, we concentrate on ND@G as a support material and provide a comprehensive overview of the methods reported for the preparation of supported metal catalysts. These include wetness impregnation (WI), incipient wetness impregnation (IWI), deposition–precipitation (DP), and the microwave-assisted polyol process (MAP), with a particular emphasis on wet chemical approaches, namely impregnation and DP, which are the most frequently employed strategies in this context. These methods are selected for their efficacy in achieving the desired dispersion and distribution of metal species on the ND@G support, which are paramount for optimizing catalytic performance. 3.2.1.1 Impregnation method The steps involved in the impregnation method for preparing supported metal catalysts can be concisely summarized into four key phases: (i) fabrication of the support material, (ii) mixing of the support with a metal precursor solution, (iii) filtration and drying to eliminate the solvent, and (iv) a high-temperature thermal treatment under a controlled atmosphere for oxidation or reduction. This method, favored for its operational simplicity and eco-economic benefits, is extensively applied, particularly in the preparation of catalysts containing precious metals [143]. The physicochemical properties of the ND@G support play a crucial role in the adsorption and dispersion of the metal precursors. Specifically, (i) the existence of defect sites and surface functional groups with high electron density, including oxygen and nitrogen, facilitates binding to metal atoms; (ii) the hydrophilicity or hydrophobicity of the ND@G surface, which significantly affects the adsorption efficiency and the size of the active metal crystallites, particularly when using water as the solvent. ND@G materials obtained at lower annealing temperatures (800–1100 °C) typically possess oxygen-containing groups (e.g., hydroxyl and ketonic groups) and a high density of defects, which confer hydrophilic properties to their surfaces. While for the ND@G obtained at higher temperature (>1200 °C), the oxygen-containing groups and the defects reduced, leading to increased hydrophobicity and decreased surface hydrophilicity. In order to strengthen the hydrophilicity of the ND@G surface, it can be treated with oxidants, such as concentrated HNO3, H2O2, and O2, to introduce more oxygen functional groups and defects [144]. On hydrophilic ND@G surfaces, the metal precursors tend to absorb on the ND@G surface uniformly, leading to the formation of ADMs. In contrast, on hydrophobic surfaces, the precursors are more likely to aggregate, forming larger NPs. Additionally, the solvent's viscosity plays a crucial role in controlling the dispersion of metal species, as higher viscosity hinders capillary action, promoting more uniform metal distribution during solvent evaporation. Moreover, the strength of metal-support interactions, which dictate how the metal precursor binds to the ND@G surface, is another key factor influencing metal dispersion. Stronger interaction helps prevent the migration of metal precursors during drying and calcination, ensuring a more uniform distribution of metal species. Beyond synthesis conditions, optimal metal dispersion is also governed by controlled metal loading. With lower metal loadings, the ND@G surface provides ample space to disperse metal atoms and reduces the risk of aggregation during post-treatment. To finely adjust the coordination number of metal cluster species, a common strategy involves the introduction of a second metal (e.g., tin) to encapsulate or segregate the aggregated island-like structures. Additionally, factors such as the choice of metal precursor, the thermal treatment temperature, and the processing atmosphere can also significantly impact the catalyst's final performance. 3.2.1.2 Deposition-precipitation method In addition to the impregnation technique, the deposition–precipitation (DP) method stands as a prevalent synthetic approach to prepare ND@G-supported active metals, achieving various sizes from ADMs to NPs by modulating the loading quantities and operational parameters [145–149]. The essence of the DP method lies in the conversion of highly soluble metal precursors into less soluble forms through pH manipulation. Typically, a precipitant, such as a basic solution, is combined with ND@G powder, followed by the gradual addition of the metal precursor into the suspension under vigorous stirring. The precursor undergoes rapid nucleation within the solution rather than on the ND@G surface. The ensuing metal precipitate, often metal hydroxides, is selectively anchored onto the ND@G support through robust interactions, including (i) carbon embedding at defect sites, and (ii) coordination of oxygen or nitrogen with functional groups. The mixture then proceeds through filtration, washing, drying, and thermal treatment to eliminate impurity ions and yield the desired catalyst. In the DP method, two critical factors can influence the uniform dispersion of the final metal centers [150]: (i) the selection of the metal precursor and precipitant to prevent particle aggregation due to the mobility of the metal precursor ions, and (ii) the adjustment of the suspension solution's pH to facilitate crystallized nucleation of the metal precursor. Often, a basic solution like sodium carbonate (Na2CO3) is used to adjust pH due to the low solubility of transition metal hydroxides [126]. As with impregnation, the metal size can be modulated by controlling the active metal loading; however, the precise control over deposition location, structural uniformity, or atomicity distribution remains a formidable challenge. Ostwald ripening has been identified as a straightforward strategy to form metal–metal bonds and construct metal clusters [151,152]. A variety of ND@G-supported ADMs, including those of Pt, Pd, Au, and Cu, have been synthesized using the DP method and applied in catalysis. Compared to the impregnation method, the DP method's distinct advantage is its ability to wash out impurity ions from the solution, particularly anions that are non-thermally decomposable, and it ensures minimal metal loss during the synthesis process. 3.2.1.3 Microwave-assisted polyol method The microwave-assisted polyol method has emerged as a simple and efficient activation technique for preparing ND@G-supported catalysts, particularly in the adsorption and deposition of metal nanoparticles onto the ND@G surface This approach has demonstrated promise in the synthesis of nanoscale metal powders. The process commences with the dispersion of surface-modified ND@G in a precursor solution that contains the active metal salt, with polyol serving as a viscous solvent and reductant, followed by microwave-assisted thermal processing. The pivotal aspect of this technique is the reduction of metallic cations within an alcoholic medium at a specific temperature. Distinguishing from traditional heating approaches such as conductive heating, hydrothermal, and solvothermal procedures [153–155], microwave irradiation stands out as a facile and scalable method, offering superior thermal uniformity and expedited reaction kinetics, as well as enhanced heating efficiency and penetration [156]. This method not only hastens the fabrication of nanoscale, high-yield, and reproducible metallic catalysts but also significantly condenses the reaction timeframe from days or hours to mere minutes [156]. Variations in microwave power yield distinct reaction energies, consequently altering reaction velocities. Moreover, it has been demonstrated that microwave power and duration can profoundly influence the dimensions and shapes of the synthesized metal species. Presently, the loading amount of metal is minimal when metals are dispersed on ND@G in the form of AMDs. The strategies to increase the loading amount of metal, without altering the dispersion should be developed. The introduction of O or N functional groups and defects on the carbon materials not only enhances the support's compatibility but also increases the anchoring sites available for the supported metal species [157]. Thereby, the modification of ND@G with O or N functional groups as well as defects may be an effective strategy to increase the concentration of AMDs on the ND@G, a strategy that merits increased focus in forthcoming research endeavors. 3.2.2 Applications of ND@G supported catalysts 3.2.2.1 Reduction reaction ND@G has been widely used to support various transition metal catalysts (e.g., Pd, Rh, Pt, Cu, Ni, Mo and etc.) for the reduction reactions, including hydrogenation and deoxygenation processes. The reaction conditions and the data regarding the catalytic performance of the corresponding catalysts are summarized in Table S2. Notably, hydrogenation, which encompasses the semi-hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds with double or triple bonds, is pivotal for the industrial synthesis of polyolefins. This process typically requires the presence of a catalyst, as spontaneous hydrogenation only occurs at elevated temperatures. Among the variety of metal catalysts, noble metals like Pd and Pt stand out for their superior catalytic performance in hydrogenation reactions. This is due to their efficient electron transfer abilities, which stem from their favorable redox potentials [1]. However, pure Pd catalysts exhibit limited selectivity in alkyne conversion, as over-hydrogenation and oligomerization remain significant challenges. During the hydrogenation process, hydrogen atoms tend to permeate into the near-surface areas of palladium (Pd) nanoparticles, generating β-hydride (β-H) complexes. These complexes are more reactive than the hydrogen that is merely adsorbed on the surface and can result in over-hydrogenation reactions. This, in turn, can decrease the selectivity for the production of alkenes or olefins [143,145,158]. Traditionally, the selectivity of alkynes semi-hydrogenation has been enhanced by poisoning Pd catalysts to curb over-hydrogenation, as seen with Lindlar catalysts, which consist of 5% Pd on CaCO3 modified by lead acetate and quinolone. However, this strategy often results in diminished intrinsic activity due to the severe poisoning of Pd and can also produce pollutants alongside the desired products [145]. Significant efforts have focused on enhancing the selectivity of Pd-based catalysts for olefin production from alkynes by altering their geometric and electronic structures. These include selectively depositing metals or metal oxides on Pd surfaces, creating bimetallic or intermetallic compounds to isolate active Pd sites, and forming single-atom Pd catalysts to modulate adsorption properties. Geometric modifications can dilute continuous Pd ensembles by incorporating a second metal element into the Pd lattice, thereby suppressing β-H species formation and curbing over-hydrogenation. Alterations in electronic structure entail disrupting the binding intensity between adsorbed molecules and the metal at the Fermi level. Such interference can result in diminished adsorption of alkenes onto the catalyst surface, thereby preventing excessive hydrogenation. The construction of palladium carbide (PdC x ) has been pinpointed as a critical determinant of catalytic selectivity for the semi-hydrogenation of alkyne. Within this context, carbon atoms positioned at the upper layers of Pd are found to decrease the generation rates of β-H and to alter the electronic configuration at the Pd surface, thereby promoting selective partial hydrogenation [145]. The metal species supported on the surface of ND@G can be dispersed into ADMs, which could facilitate the formation of PdC x , thereby enhancing the selectivity of the Pd catalyst. Liu et al. developed a strategy for preparing Pd catalysts comprising isolated Pd atoms and Pd clusters anchored on ND@G(1100 °C) for the hydrogenation of nitriles [126]. These catalysts demonstrated over 98% selectivity for the production of secondary and primary amines at 40°C in methanol (Reaction conditions: solvent, 10 mL methanol; 0.5 mmol benzonitrile (BN); 10 mg catalyst; reductant, 3 mmol ammonia borane). They discovered that the selectivity of nitrile hydrogenation can be effectively modulated by structurally regulating atomically dispersed Pd catalysts. The intermediate benzylideneimine was more prone to condensation on Pd1/ND@G, leading to the formation of dibenzylamine (DBA). In contrast, benzylamine (BA), which is more readily hydrogenated, was predominantly formed on the Pd n /ND@G catalyst. The increased selectivity for BA over Pd n /ND@G was attributed to the overly strong hydrogenation activity on Pd clusters. Corroborating findings have emerged from additional research teams. Chen et al. showed that the single Rh atoms supported on ND@G-1100 (Rh1/ND@G-1100) have better selectivity towards DBA, exceeding 99%, compared to the cluster Rh n /ND@G in BN hydrogenation, as Rh1 active sites exhibit a reduced propensity forBA formation (Fig. 9 e). The decreased selectivity of DBA in Rh n /ND@G was attributed to the overly strong hydrogenation activity on Rh clusters. Additionally, the Rh1/ND@G catalyst was determined to exhibit 36-fold greater catalytic activity compared to Pd1/ND@G and 42-fold greater than Ru1/ND@G. Meanwhile, Pt1/ND@G and Ir1/ND@G showed minimal activity under the same conditions [127]. In addition to nitrile selective hydrogenation, the selective hydrogenation of carbon–carbon unsaturated bonds can be also achieved over the atomically dispersed Pd species supported by ND@G. Huang's research explored the correlation between the catalysts’ structural properties and their catalytic performance during acetylene selective hydrogenation. This was done by using Pd1/ND@G and Pd n /ND@G catalysts [9,145,160–164]. The Pd1/ND@G catalyst demonstrated superior activity, selectivity, and stability, outperforming Pd catalysts supported on traditional materials such as CNTs, Al2O3, SiO2, MgAl2O4, and MgO. This catalyst maintained its exceptional performance at 180 °C for over 30 h with no signs of deactivation or sintering, and no aggregation of metallic atoms being detected (Fig. 9d). Conversely, the Pd n /ND@G catalyst, despite its high activity at ambient temperatures, exhibited poor selectivity towards ethylene, as the ethylene was readily converted into ethane. In the Pd1/ND@G catalyst, the individual Pd atoms were firmly anchored to the ND@G support, embedded within defective sited of the graphene framework through covalent linkages with three carbon atoms, forming the PdC x species with a tetrahedral configuration. This Pd–C binding in Pd1/ND@G significantly enhances catalytic selectivity by inhibiting the generation of β-H species, facilitating the release of C2H4* intermediates from the surface, and preventing additional hydrogenation that would convert ethylene to ethane. This is in stark contrast to Pd nanoclusters, which are more susceptible to over-hydrogenation and oligomerization processes. Additionally, Pd1/ND@G avoids acetylene oligomerization and coking, contributing to its excellent stability, consistent with previous findings [126]. In propyne semi-hydrogenation tests, the Pd1/ND@G catalyst also exhibited excellent catalytic performance, achieving 88% propyne conversion and 98% propene selectivity at 280 °C (Table S2). The superior selectivity of Pd1/ND@G (97%–100%) was maintained across the entire reaction temperature range from 220 to 280 °C and reactants flow rates from 25 to 220 mL min−1, surpassing that of Pd n /ND@G (64%–98%). Pd1/ND@G achieved its maximum propyne conversion of 98% and propene selectivity of 96% at 240 °C and 220 mL min−1. In contrast, Pd n /ND@G showed minimal variation in propyne conversion (87%–100%) across different temperatures and flow rates, but lower flow rates and longer contact times reduced propene selectivity due to β-H formation and over-hydrogenation to propane. Furtherly, Huang et al. investigated the catalytic performance of Pd catalysts supported by different nanocarbon substrates, including ND@G, OLC, and CNT, for the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. They noted that the Pd catalyst on ND@G showed lower initial reactivity but had a markedly higher selectivity for styrene production compared to Pd catalysts supported on OLC and CNT. The researchers attributed this to the formation of PdC x carbide in Pd/ND@G catalyst due to strong metal-support interactions, which alters the electron structure of Pd atoms, diminishing the capacity to active H2 molecules. Consequently, the catalyst's activity was diminished, but this effectively inhibited the excessive hydrogenation of styrene, thereby enhancing the selectivity for alkenes [165]. In addition to the formation of PdC x on the surface of ND@G, the atomically ordered Pd-based intermetallic compounds on the ND@G can also enhance the selectivity for alkenes. Intermetallic catalysts, compared to their traditional alloy counterparts, may surpass the limitations of disordered structures by leveraging unique ordered atomic frameworks and homogeneous active sites, leading to efficient disruption of Pd–Pd ensembles and enhanced alkene selectivity through controlled adsorption properties. Wang et al. used a wet-impregnation method to prepare Pd3Pb intermetallic NPs on ND@G for alkyne semihydrogenation [143]. The synthesized small-sized Pd3Pb intermetallic catalyst (Fig. 10 a–d) displayed impressive catalytic efficiency, achieving a TOF value of 932 h−1 for phenylacetylene semi-hydrogenation at mild conditions (25 °C and 0.3 MPa H2, solvent: 2 mL ethanol, phenylacetylene: 1 mmol, catalyst: 0.1 at.% Pd). This catalyst also demonstrated a high selectivity exceeding 96% for the production of styrene with a near-complete conversion of phenylacetylene (Table S2), which is significantly enhanced compared to that of monometallic Pd/ND@G catalyst. The enhanced selectivity of the Pd3Pb/ND@G catalyst for phenylacetylene semi-hydrogenation was ascribed to its geometric and electronic factors. The ordered Pd3Pb alloy structure weakens Pd–Pd bonding, preventing β-H formation and improving selective hydrogenation. Further theoretical studies suggest that incorporating Pb into Pd can cause a downward shift in the d-band center in relation to the Fermi level, which diminishes the adsorption energy of unsaturated bonds. This reduction in double bond adsorption strength leads to an accelerated desorption of styrene from the Pd-Pb intermetallic alloy surface, inhibiting subsequent over-hydrogenation. Moreover, the ordered structure of Pd3Pb/ND@G was maintained during cyclic tests, with no sintering observed, likely due to the distinct/strong metal-support interactions between Pd3Pb and defective-rich graphene layers of ND@G. Conversely, supports such as OLC and XC, which possess perfect graphitized surfaces, are deficient in defects, hindering the formation of strong interactions with Pd3Pb. The TOF values of Pd3Pb/OLC and Pd3Pb/XC are markedly lower than that of Pd3Pb/ND@G under identical reaction conditions (Fig. 10d). This work furtherly indicates that the ND@G is also an outstanding carbonaceous support for intermetallic compounds compared to other traditional carbon materials. To overcome the constraints related to Pb, researchers have prepared an innovative PdCu3 intermetallic catalyst supported on ND@G, showcasing remarkable catalytic performance, with a TOF value of 2940 h−1—six times higher than the commercial Lindlar catalyst—along with exceptional selectivity of 95% for the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene to styrene (25 °C and 0.4 MPa H2) [166]. The recycling experiments for PdCu3/ND@G were also conducted at a partial conversion level of approximately 50%to assess its stability. It was demonstrated that the phenylacetylene conversion remained within the range of 48%–53% over four consecutive cycles. Additionally, the catalyst exhibited a nearly constant and remarkable selectivity towards styrene (>98%) throughout all cycles, showcasing its exceptional stability. The authors also synthesized a dual-atom catalyst featuring a bonded Pd1Cu1 atomic pair on ND@G, which exhibits higher reactivity than their corresponding single-atom Pd1 or Cu1 catalysts for low-temperature hydrogenation reactions, achieving complete acetylene removal and 92% selectivity for ethylene [140]. The enhanced catalytic performance of Pd1Cu1/ND@G over both Pd1/ND@G and Cu1/ND@G indicates the cooperative interaction between the Pd atom and Cu atoms. The Pd1Cu1 diatom pair provides a beneficial steric configuration and a distinct modulated electronic coupling structure of the Pd–C bond and Cu–Pd bond. These promoted the adsorption and activation of the reactants (H2/C2H2) and the desorption of C2H4 product on Pd1Cu1/ND@G, and finally obtained enhanced catalytic activity for acetylene hydrogenation and increased selectivity for ethylene production [167]. Though Pd-based catalysts show high efficiency in the hydrogenation of double and triple bonds and in preventing the over-hydrogenation of unwanted products, the considerable expense associated with Pd has spurred the search for more economical catalytic alternatives. There is a strong desire to prepare novel catalysts using inexpensive, environmentally friendly, and abundant transition metals like Cu, Fe, Ni, or Ce to achieve comparable catalytic performance to that of Pd-based catalysts [168]. Sun et al. investigated atomic Cu on ND@G (Cu/ND@G) for phenylacetylene selective hydrogenation [19]. They found that Cu/ND@G showed improved activity compared to Cu/ND (ND: pristine ND) under the same conditions (Reaction conditions: atmospheric pressure at 20 °C, 0.02 Mstock solutionof phenylacetylene in ethanol at a flow rate of 0.6 mL min−1 with an H2 flow rate of 12 mL min−1) (Fig. 11 a).
