Due to the interaction between the defective sp 2 graphene layers of ND@G and Cu2+ precursors, the well-dispersed Cu species on ND@G with a proper proportion of Cu0, Cu+, and Cu2+ were formed, which are responsible for the enhanced selective-hydrogenation performance. Huang and co-authors compared the catalytic performance of Cu1/ND@G and Cu n /ND@G for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene [134]. They demonstrated that Cu1/ND@G displayed enhanced catalytic performance with high acetylene conversion of 95% and high ethylene selectivity of 98%, in comparison to the Cu n /ND@G (reaction condition: 200 °C; 1% C2H2, 10% H2, 20% C2H4 gas mix balanced with He; GHSV = 3000 h−1) (Fig. 11b). More importantly, the Cu1/ND@G catalyst demonstrated excellent durability, maintaining its performance for 60 h at 200 °C (inset in Fig. 11b). They claimed that the single Cu atom bonded with three C atoms (forming a three-coordination) in the Cu1/ND@G (Fig. 11d), forming the positively charged single Cu atoms (Cu+, Cu2+), which facilitated the activation of acetylene and the desorption of ethylene. This not only enhanced the selectivity for ethylene production but also enhanced catalytic activity for acetylene hydrogenation, which is different from that observed on Pd1/ND@G catalyst. The same research group also loaded a single Cu atom on nitrogen-doped ND@G (ND@NG), obtained Cu1/ND@NG catalyst, to investigate the effect of coordination environments of Cu atoms on their catalytic activity. They found that Cu1/ND@G with Cu–C bond exhibits higher catalytic activity than Cu1/ND@NG with Cu–N bond for acetylene selective hydrogenation. The authors claimed that the Cu–N bond in the Cu1/ND@NG catalyst led to more positively charged Cu atoms compared to that in Cu1/ND@G, and the Cu atoms in the Cu–C configuration favor the H–H bond dissociation (adsorption and activation) and ethylene desorption, thus accelerating the acetylene hydrogenation [133]. The results clearly elucidate the importance of the coordination environments of single metal atoms in catalysts for acetylene selective hydrogenation, consistent with previous studies of the Cu1/ND@G catalysts [19]. ND@G-supported Ni catalyst has also been investigated by Golubina and co-authors, but a different hydrogenation performance was reported [169]. They found that the pristine-supported Ni (Ni/ND) catalyst showed significantly higher selectivity for styrene production than Ni/ND@G in selective phenylacetylene hydrogenation (Fig. 11c), which is in contrast to that of ND@G supported Cu catalyst [19]. They claimed that the oxygen functional groups on ND could strengthen the metal-support interaction through chemical coordination of the Ni–O–C bonds in the Ni/ND catalyst, while the interaction between Ni NPs and ND@G is weak for the absence of most oxygen groups. We suspect the exceeding loading of Ni might be the main reason for its weakly bonded Ni species in the ND@G catalyst because the size of Ni species with nanoparticle form is much higher than that of the defective sites on graphene shells. In addition, this work indicates that the introduction of oxygen groups could also enhance the metal-support interaction, regulating the electronic configuration of the metal atoms. In addition to the selective hydrogenation of alkyne (acetylene, phenylacetylene), the catalytic hydrogenation reduction of CO2 has also been explored over ND@G-supported catalysts. Specifically, ND@G has been utilized to anchor MoC x nanoparticles, which are an active phase for CO2 hydrogenation reduction across a range of temperatures from 400 to 600 °C due to their proficiency in C=O bond dissociation and H2 molecule cleavage [170]. This catalyst showed remarkable catalytic performance in the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction, achieving nearly 99% CO selectivity at an H2/CO2 ratio of 4, with CO2 conversions of 37.4% at 400 °C and 64% at 600 °C, closely approaching equilibrium values of 41.3% and 65%, respectively. The MoC x /ND@G catalyst exhibits improved CO2 activation at lower temperatures compared to MoC x supported on supports such as activated carbon and γ-Al2O3. This enhancement is due to the strong interaction between the MoC x species and the curved graphitic layers present on the surface of ND@G. Furthermore, the ND@G support promoted the distribution of MoC x nanoclusters, and increased the number of reactive sites available for reaction. 3.2.2.2 Oxidation reaction Metal catalysts supported on ND@G have also been demonstrated to exhibit exceptional performance in oxidation reactions, such as dehydrogenation, CO oxidation, and electrocatalysis, due to their distinctive electronic configurations and enhanced surface reactivity. In the production of olefins, the dehydrogenation of alkanes presents an alternative pathway that is highly efficient, facilitates product separation, and incurs lower costs, in addition to the semi-hydrogenation of alkynes [171–174]. Traditional iron oxide-based catalysts necessitate excessive steam and high reaction temperatures exceeding 600 °C to achieve satisfactory olefin yields in direct dehydrogenation (DDH) processes, due to thermodynamic and kinetic constraints. This leads to substantial energy and water consumption, as well as catalyst deactivation from aggregation, sintering, thermal degradation, and coke formation [173,175,176]. The formation of coke, an undesired side reaction, poses a significant challenge in dehydrogenation processes, with its underlying mechanisms being a subject of ongoing research. Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst are believed to initiate the nucleation of olefins and kinds of paraffin, which can result in the creation of extensive graphitic coke structures. The accumulation of coke can either encase or obstruct the active components of the catalyst, leading to its deactivation. The carbon-based metal-free catalysts showed resistance to coke formation during DDH reactions [177]. However, the reaction temperatures in these investigations are still as elevated as 550 °C, which does not significantly contribute to energy savings. Given the excellent activity of noble metals such as Pd, Pt, Ir, Rh, and Ru, ND@G-supported noble metals with well-dispersed atomic forms have garnered significant research interest for their promising low-temperature activity in DDH reactions. Chen et al. synthesized a range of Pt-based catalysts supported on ND@G, encompassing Pt1/ND@G (single Pt atom), Pt n /ND@G (Pt clusters), and Pt p /ND@G (Pt NPs), to catalyze the DDH reaction of n-butane (Reaction conditions: 450 °C, GHSV = 18000 mL g cat. - 1 h−1, n-C4H10:H2 = 1:1 with He balance). They found that the fully exposed Pt3 clusters displayed exceptional catalytic efficacy in the DDH reaction of n-butane, with enhanced alkene selectivity compared to their monometallic and nanoparticulate counterparts (Fig. 12 a and b). This superiority of Pt3 clusters is attributed to the facilitated was ineffective for initiating the activation of the C–H bond in cyclohexane and the following dehydrogenation reaction at a temperature of 280 °C [178,179]. Conversely, larger Pt nanoparticles, with higher Pt–Pt coordination numbers, were more susceptible to poisoning by side reactions, including coke deposition, hydrogenolysis, and cracking, leading to diminished activity. Optimal catalytic performance was achieved with fully exposed few-atom Pt ensembles (Pt3/ND@G), due to their elevated d-band center and the presence of multiple neighboring Pt sites, which ease the activation of C–H bonds. Additionally, they display weaker affinities for alkene products, promoting alkene desorption and preventing catalyst poisoning (Fig. 12c–g). Chen et al. have recently conducted a comparison of the dehydrogenation efficiency of various single-atom metal catalysts for alkane molecules. They prepared Pt1/ND@G, Ir1/ND@G, and Pd1/ND@G catalysts via impregnation and evaluated their catalytic performance in butane dehydrogenation [118]. It was found that Ir1/ND@G (TOF = 0.48 s−1) significantly outperformed the other catalysts in both conversion and reaction rate for n-butane. TPSR characterization indicated that the Ir1/ND@G is more facile to activate the first and second C–H bonds, which is the rate-determining step, than Pt1/ND@G and Pd1/ND@G. In other words, butane dehydrogenation to 1-C4H9* has a lower barrier and is more exothermic on Ir ensemble sites. Furthermore, the catalytic performances of various Ir species with different structures were investigated in butane dehydrogenation. Unlike Pt, as the Ir nanoscale decreases, Ir1/ND@G (0.02 wt% loading) with maximized atomic utilization exhibited the highest reaction rate (8.8 mol g Ir - 1 h−1) and selectivity towards butene (>95%). The dehydrogenation rate-determining step was found to depend on the Ir species structure, with C–H activation on Ir1/ND@G playing a primary role rather than butene desorption on Ir n /ND@G due to strong adsorption of intermediates. Beyond the dehydrogenation of alkanes, Tian et al. evaluated the catalytic performance of various metal catalysts (Ru, Ir, Pt and Pd) supported on ND@G in the dehydrogenative cross-coupling reaction. This reaction is crucial for synthesizing α-hydroxycarboxylic acids from ethylene glycol and primary alcohols, which are derived from biomass resources [180,181]. Ru/ND@G notably demonstrated the best performance, with activity and selectivity comparable to homogeneous catalytic processes. The catalytically active sites on Ru/ND@G were identified as isolated Ru atoms and fully exposed clusters that possess a certain number of surface atoms during the reaction. Although ND@G-supported atomically dispersed metal catalysts have been successfully synthesized and shown superior dehydrogenation catalytic performance compared to nanoparticle catalysts, achieving precise control over their structural uniformity through simple deposition–precipitation strategies remains challenging. Moreover, the small clusters are thermodynamically unstable, limiting their application to high-temperature reactions. Enhancing the thermal stability of noble metal-based catalysts often involves the addition of a secondary metal, such as Sn, In, Cu, or Zn, through the co-impregnation method. This approach not only enhances the distribution and reactivity of the active sites but also aids in preventing their agglomeration and sintering under high-temperature reaction conditions. Zhang prepared Sn-assisted fully exposed Pt clusters on ND@G support (Pt3Sn/ND@G) to catalyze the DDH reaction of n-butane (Reaction conditions: 450 °C. GHSV = 18000 mL gcat −1h−1, n-butane/H2 = 1:1 with He balance) [182]. This catalyst achieved exceptional selectivity (>98%) towards olefin products during the n-butane dehydrogenation reaction, with a TOF value being about 3.9 times greater than that of both Pt3Sn/Al2O3 and Pt/ND@G (Fig. 13 a–d). Moreover, it was found that only a slight deactivation after 18 h (from 40.9% to 35.6%) was observed. And the Pt/ND@G showed an obvious deactivation (from about 25% to 15%). In a long-term reaction test, the activity of a-PtSn/ND@G remained at a rather high level, and the selectivity toward C4 olefin was > 98% after 50 h reaction. These indicate that the stability of the Pt-based catalysts was also enhanced. This enhancement is attributed to the partition assistance of the Sn agent and the defective-rich core-shell structure of the ND@G support, which ensures full Pt availability/exposure to reactants, high thermal stability (sintering-resistant), and optimal adsorption/desorption behavior. Nevertheless, exerting fine control over the metal coordination within clusters and profoundly comprehending how varying quantities of Sn affect the dehydrogenation performance of PtSn/ND@G catalysts remain significant challenges for the scientific community. In related work, the same research group synthesized a series of ND@G-supported Pt cluster catalysts with different atomic ratios of Sn to Pt (0.85, 1.7, 3.4, and 6.8). They evaluated the catalytic performance of these catalysts in the dehydrogenation of n-butane [139]. The results, including the conversion rate of n-butane and the selectivity towards C4 olefins, across these catalysts are summarized in Fig. 13 and Table S3. It has been found that the catalytic performance of PtSn/ND@G was significantly amplified, particularly with the PtSn1.75/ND@G catalyst, which demonstrated exceptionally high selectivity for C4 olefin (>99.0%) and a substantial conversion rate of n-butane, decreasing from an initial 35.4% to 30.9% after a duration of 10 h. However, an excess of Sn species in PtSn3.4/ND@G and PtSn6.8/ND@G catalysts led to a marked decline in the conversion rate of n-butane, despite maintaining similar C4 olefin selectivity. The excess Sn, with a ratio greater than 1.7, hindered the enhancement of Pt dispersion by obscuring Pt clusters. This led to a reduction in Pt dispersion from 99.1% to 5.6%, limiting the availability of active Pt atoms for reactant adsorption. This finding suggests that an improper introduction of a secondary metal can obscure active sites, diminishing atomic efficiency. Additionally, a new approach has been suggested for the formation of fully exposed Pt clusters on Sn-modified ND@G substrates (Sn-ND@G), which is different from the conventional technique of co-depositing Pt and Sn onto ND@G. The pre-decorated Sn and the existing defects on the ND@G surface could spatially isolate and stabilize the subsequently loaded Pt atoms, thereby obtaining Pt clusters on Sn-ND@G (Fig. 13g). The prepared Pt/Sn-ND@G displayed a robust TOF value of 136.2 h−1 with 99.7% selectivity for styrene at 500 °C in DDH of ethylbenzene to styrene, outperforming conventional Pt/ND@G catalysts. The spatial separation of atomically dispersed Sn species, in combination with the defects on ND@G, facilitates the dispersion of Pt species. This arrangement leads to an increased number of active sites per unit of Pt, thereby markedly improving the specific catalytic activity of the Pt/Sn-ND@G catalyst. Other metals, such as Rh, Ru, and Ir, were also loaded on the Sn-ND@G. Similarly, M/Sn-ND@G catalysts demonstrated significantly enhanced catalytic performance when compared to their M/ND@G counterparts, indicating the broadly beneficial effects of Sn modification on ND@G [74]. ND@G-supported metal catalysts have also been utilized to catalyze other oxidative reactions. Zhang et al. discovered that the Pd catalyst on ND@G (900 °C) (Pd/ND@G) exhibited enhanced catalytic activity in the oxidation of CO, achieving a conversion rate of ∼ 56% at 120 °C, surpassing Pd supported on OLC (Pd/OLC), which showed a 13% CO conversion (Fig. 14 a–d). Under both O2-rich and O2-stoichiometric conditions, the temperatures required for half CO conversion (50%) over Pd/ND@G were lower than that for Pd/OLC catalysts. It was found that Pd/ND@G exhibits higher metal dispersion than Pd/OLC, owing to the strong interaction between palladium and the defective graphene layers within the ND@G support. This interaction promotes the supported Pd species dispersed into Pd clusters and even single Pd atoms for the Pd/ND@G catalyst. Consequently, the geometric and electronic configurations of Pd on ND@G are altered, which reduces CO adsorption, enhances O2 activation on Pd atoms, and ultimately boosts the catalytic activity of Pd/ND@G for the oxidation of CO. In addition, the Ru/ND@G catalyst was also investigated in CO oxidation. It was also observed that the catalyst exhibited strong metal-support interaction (SMSI), which led to more Ru clusters and single Ru atoms compared to that in Ru/OLC. However, Ru/ND@G showed lower catalytic activity than Ru/OLC, which is different from that of Pd/ND@G system. The in-situ DRIFT investigation showed that the SMSI in Ru/ND@G results in a strong twin CO adsorption on Ru atoms, which results in a lower catalytic activity for CO oxidation. The results obtained from these two pieces of research indicate that the SMSI in ND@G-supported catalysts may play different roles in their catalytic activity. Certainly, further systematic and comprehensive researches are needed to uncover the underlying mechanisms responsible for the different behaviors of ND-supported ruthenium-based and palladium-based catalysts in CO oxidation reactions. 3.2.2.3 Electrochemistry The activity, selectivity, and durability of an electrocatalyst are paramount to the operational efficiency and lifespan of a battery. The support material is instrumental in maintaining the activity and durability of metal catalysts [114,184–190]. Nano-carbon materials, renowned for their expansive surface area and surface defects, as well as their electrical properties, are commonly utilized as support materials in electrocatalysis to facilitate the dispersion of catalytic components and electron transfer during the reaction process sp 2 [191]. However, conventional carbonaceous materials, such as carbon black (CB) and activated carbon (AC), frequently experience corrosion and suffer from irreversible structural damage when subjected to the high-potential and high-temperature conditions present in fuel cells (FCs) [184–190]. The degradation of carbon support structures can lead to the loss, agglomeration, and sintering of active metal species, which may render the electrocatalyst ineffective and could also result in the breakdown of the electrode. Therefore, it is essential for the practical application of FCs to develop advanced and durable carbon materials that can endure the severe conditions of the cathode, characterized by high oxygen concentrations, substantial electrochemical potentials, and either acidic or alkaline environments. ND@G material stands out as a potential candidate for stable electrocatalysts’ support or even as a metal-free electrocatalyst. Its properties include excellent thermal and electrochemical conductivity, resistance to corrosion across a broad potential range, and a low background current in both aqueous and non-aqueous mediums. These outstanding properties render it an ideal support for electrocatalysts. In contrast to conventional carbon materials, the graphitic shell of ND@G on the surface imparts distinctive physicochemical characteristics due to its elevated curvature and high surface energy. This enhances electrical conductivity and the affinity for metal nanoparticles. Furthermore, the sp 3 diamond core acts as a sturdy foundation for the sp 2 graphene shell, averting the self-aggregation that often occurs in large, flat basal planes of pristine sp 2 carbon materials, especially under oxidative conditions. Within the field of electrochemistry, metal electrocatalysts supported on ND@G have demonstrated superior performance in electrocatalytic reactions involving the oxidation of alcohols and the reduction of oxygen molecules (both surface sensitive). The reaction conditions and the catalysts’ parameters, including the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of Pt particles, Tafel slope, and background current, which are crucial indicators of electrocatalytic activity, are detailed in Table S5. Zang et al. prepared ND@G (1100 °C) supported Pt catalyst (Pt/ND@G) via a microwave-assisted polyol reduction technique and investigated their electrochemical properties and electrocatalytic performance in aqueous solutions [192]. The synthesized Pt/ND@G catalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic activity and durability during the electro-oxidation of methanol, outperforming the unannealed ND-supported Pt catalyst (Pt/ND) synthesized under identical parameters (Fig. 15 a and b, Table S5). Compared to the ND, ND@G is with a sp 2-bonded shell, which fosters a stronger interaction with Pt, owing to the electrons' delocalization in the graphitic layer and the d-electrons of Pt, which leads to a higher dispersion of Pt NPs on ND@G surface—a key factor in boosting the electrocatalytic efficiency of Pt. The authors also explored the effect of annealing temperature on ND with larger sizes (50–100 nm) for direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs). In related research, Zhang et al. prepared ND@G composites by annealing NDs (50 nm) in a vacuum at 1200 and 1500 °C for 1 h and used them as support materials for supporting Pt NPs to develop advanced electrocatalysts for DMFCs [193]. The Pt/ND@G also showed superior catalytic activity and durability for the electro-oxidation reaction of methanol (MOR) compared to that of Pt/ND (Fig. 15c and d). It was found that the durability of Pt/ND@G catalysts is influenced by the annealing temperature of ND@G supports, with Pt/ND@G(1200 °C) demonstrating superior catalytic stability over Pt/ND@G(1500 °C). Although the Pt/ND@G(1500 °C) initially displayed a higher current, its swift decline suggested inferior stability. This may result from the increase in the thickness of the graphene-like shell from 2 to 3 to 10–14 layers as the annealing temperature is elevated from 1200 to 1500 °C, which could lead to graphene layer stacking under oxidizing conditions. However, Dong et al. reported an inverse finding. They prepared Pt/ND@G electrocatalysts using the microwave heating polyol method after annealing ND at 1300 and 1600 °C in a vacuum for 1.5 h for the oxygen reduction reaction [194]. They found that Pt/ND@G (1600 °C) exhibited greater stability than Pt/ND@G(1300 °C), attributing this to the SMSI in Pt/ND@G(1600 °C) and the high stability of the ND@G(1600 °C) support in acid solutions, which effectively prevents oxidation corrosion due to a more regular graphitic structure in the shell. Discrepancies in findings among various researchers suggest that there is a need for more comprehensive and thorough investigations in the future, to identify the principal factors influencing performances. It is well known that Pt catalysts readily adsorb intermediates, including CO and other ions in MOR, poisoning the active sites and reducing reaction rates. Moreover, Pt experiences slow kinetics at the cathode with over potentials of approximately 0.3–0.4 V for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). To address these issues, the introduction of secondary reducible metal elements to form Pt-M intermetallic alloy nanoparticles has been proposed. This approach aims to lessen the impact of CO adsorption-induced poisoning in MOR as well as to lower the overpotentials in ORR. Such alloys as PtRu, PtNi, PtFe, and PtCo have been developed with the aim of boosting the catalytic performance and efficiency [195,196]. Wang et al. evaluated PtNi electrocatalyst supported on ND@G(1300 °C) for catalyzing anodic MOR and cathodic ORR (Fig. 16 a) [195]. Through co-reduction, a uniform distribution of nano-sized PtNi alloy particles was achieved on ND@G. The synthesized PtNi/ND@G catalyst showed enhanced electrocatalytic activities for both MOR and ORR when compared to the pure Pt catalyst also supported by ND@G (Pt/ND@G). Investigates showed that the presence of Ni facilitated the production of oxygenated species at lower potentials, which in turn increased the reaction of rate of methanol electro-oxidation. Additionally, Ni is instrumental in the kinetics of oxygen reduction, promoting the detachment of ORR intermediates from adjacent platinum active sites due to changes in crystal structure upon alloying. Furthermore, improved durability was observed for the Pt-M alloy supported on ND@G compared to the conventional carbon support Vulcan XC-72 in the MOR, consistent with previous results [192–194]. Besides Pt-based alloys, metal oxides (MnO2, ZnO2, and TiO2) and metallic carbides (TiC) have also been applied to enhance the electrocatalytic efficiency and durability of Pt-based catalysts. Zhao et al. prepared a Pt catalyst supported by TiC modified ND@G (Pt/TiC-ND@G) via the microwave-assisted polyol method for MOR and ORR processes (Fig. 16b) [197]. The Pt/TiC-ND@G catalyst exhibited an anodic oxidation current density of 57.5 mA cm−2, marking a roughly five times enhancement over the 12 mA cm−2 observed for the Pt/ND@G catalyst. Moreover, the Pt-TiC/ND@G catalyst displayed a more negative initial potential of 0.21 V, indicating a greater tendency for the MOR compared to the Pt/ND@G catalyst, which had an initial potential of 0.41 V. The superior electrocatalytic efficiency and durability of the Pt/TiC-ND@G catalyst are due to the robust chemical bonds between the TiC layer and Pt particles, ensuring their stable anchorage, minimizing their movement and clustering. The TiC layer also reduces electrical resistance at the boundary between platinum and the ND@G support, thus accelerating electron transport within the catalyst layer. Overall, these characteristics enhance the exceptional electrocatalytic efficiency and stability of the Pt/TiC-ND@G catalyst. The same researchers observed similar findings by replacing TiC with TiO2 [20]. The TiO2-modified ND@G was fabricated via microwave hydrolysis and subsequently utilized to synthesize Pt/TiO2-ND@G electrocatalysts through a microwave-assisted reduction process [20]. It showed enhanced electrocatalytic performance in both MOR and ORR, outperforming its unmodified counterparts. Moreover, Pt catalysts supported on TiO2-ND@G displayed superior durability than those on carbon black and TiO2-C. This superiority in durability is believed to stem from the remarkable stability of the TiO2/ND@G support and the firm attachment of Pt nanoparticles through the TiO2 interface. Overall, the introduction of other chemical components on Pt-based catalysts would improve their efficiency and durability in electrocatalytic reactions (e.g., MOR and ORR, etc.) through changing crystal structure, increasing active sites, or strengthening metal-support interaction. Additionally, doping carbon support with heteroatoms is another widespread strategy to enhance the catalytic performance of metal catalysts supported on carbon supports. Wu et al. developed a bi-functional catalyst featuring cobalt (Co) supported on N-doped ND@G support (Co/ND@NG) [198]. The Co/ND@NG demonstrated excellent catalytic activities for both the ORR and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER)in alkaline conditions (Fig. 16c and d). It displayed an almost ideal four-electron transfer process for ORR and exhibited a catalytic efficiency comparable to the traditional Pt/C catalyst that contains 20 wt% Pt. Compared to Co/CB-N (CB-N: N-doped carbon black) synthesized under identical conditions, Co/ND@NG exhibited enhanced durability, which was ascribed to the cooperative interaction between the cobalt-nitrogen components within the graphitic carbon shell and the exceptional stability of the ND core. 3.2.2.4 Enzymatic reaction In recent developments, ND@G hybrid materials supporting fully exposed metal clusters have emerged as promising candidates in the realm of nanozymes—a category of nanomaterials that mimic enzymatic catalysis, garnering attention for their high stability, catalytic efficacy, and efficient utilization of atoms [30,84,199–201]. The coordination architecture of these isolated metal clusters with ND@G can be meticulously engineered and customized by establishing metal–carbon linkages on the defective graphene surface, offering not only proximate metal atoms as catalytic centers but also a spectrum of structural configurations and catalytic potentials. Meng et al. fabricated a variety of Cu-based catalysts with varying dimensions anchored on ND@G and identified that the fully exposed Cu clusters, averaging three metal atoms per cluster (Cu3/ND@G), displayed remarkable oxidase-like activity, indicative of potent antibacterial capabilities (Fig. 17 ) [30]. The activity Cu3/ND@G is significantly higher than that of Cu1/ND@G and Cu p /ND@G (Fig. 17). It was revealed that the synergetic interaction among adjacent Cu atoms in the Cu3 cluster guarantees effective activation of O2 and the easy desorption of •OH, resulting in increased oxidase-like activity by the Cu3/ND@G. Furthermore, the same research group reported that a Pd cluster supported on ND@G material exhibits superior catalytic antibacterial properties. This discovery underscores the potential of precisely tailored metal clusters on ND@G to serve as efficient nanozymes, highlighting their utility in applications where enzyme-like catalytic action is desired. 4 Conclusions and perspectives The development of ND@G offers a special and promising material family for preparing catalysts with outstanding catalytic performance. This ND-derived material, defined by its high electron density, partial electron delocalization, and distinct surface defects, serves as a unique chemical interface between catalytic active sites and the reaction environment. With these adjustable surface physicochemical-electronic properties, ND@G has been effectively employed as a unique class of metal-free catalysts, initiating activity at defect sites stemming from alterations in charge density within carbon regions. Moreover, it also has been utilized to support metal NPs, clusters, and even single metal atoms. To profoundly understand and enhance their catalytic behavior, it is imperative to distinguish the role of each component and their synergistic interactions, even those often neglected points. While certain properties of ND@G have been documented in the reported literature, much remains unexplored, and needs to be realized by more efforts. This review firstly presents a summary of the sp 3/sp 2 hybrid structure formation as well as the key technologies for characterizing the physiochemical properties of ND@G. Typically, ND@G, featuring a nanodiamond core enclosed by a graphitic shell, is produced by subjecting pristine nanodiamonds to high-temperature annealing (between 800 to 1400 °C) within an inert gas atmosphere or under vacuum conditions. With the increase in annealing temperature from 800 to 1400 °C, the thickness of the graphitic shell grows from 1 to 2 carbon atomic layers to 5–9 carbon atomic layers. Furthermore, the quantity of surface oxygen-containing groups and defects on the graphitic shell is observed to decrease with the rise in annealing temperature. Thus, the physicochemical properties of ND@G could be well regulated by varying annealing temperatures. Another strategy to tailor ND@G’s physicochemical properties is doping heteroatoms, such as N, P, B, and so on. Based on the doping mothed, the surface of ND@G can be obviously changed and introduce some unknown properties, which should be thoroughly considered and characterized. A variety of characteristic technologies are employed to investigate the distinctive physicochemical properties, including the core-shell architecture, surface functional groups, and the defective graphitic shell. These investigations have facilitated a more profound comprehension of the transforming processes from pristine ND to the core-shell structured ND@G, along with the relationship between their structural features and catalytic performance. Nevertheless, those unnoticed properties might be the real reason for some activity. We need to combine those different techniques to comprehensively understand the carbon surface chemistry of the material. Subsequently, this review comprehensively summarizes the catalytic applications of ND@G in a variety of catalytic processes, including hydrogenation, aerobic oxidation, dehydrogenation, oxidative decomposition of organic pollutants, electrochemical reactions, and Enzymatic reaction. It explores ND@G's role both as a metal-free catalyst and as a support for metal catalysts, which constitutes the main focus of the review. Summarized key points from the literature include: (1) As a metal-free catalyst, ND@G has surprisingly demonstrated superior catalytic performance compared to other carbon materials, such as CNTs, graphene, and activated carbon, and even in comparison to metal-based catalysts in many catalytic processes. This exceptional efficiency is attributed to its unique hybrid sp 3/sp 2 core-shell structure, featuring an ND core and a curved graphene layer-shell, as well as the presence of residual surface oxygen functional groups and defective sites on the graphene layer shell of ND@G. The ND core might have some influence on the surface reaction, but there is still no direct evidence or convincing hypothesis on how they exert the influence. It has been observed that the active sites differ across various catalytic reactions, with synergistic effects between different sites sometimes playing a crucial role. Moreover, investigations into heteroatom doping have also been conducted to further improve the catalytic performance of ND@G. The introduction of heteroatoms into ND@G can modulate their electron-donor properties, which in turn boosts catalytic performance. Co-doping with multiple heteroatoms in ND@G can effectively create a greater number of active sites than individual doping and may even lead to the formation of the frustrated Lewis pairs. Undoubtedly, the doping process not only brings dopants on the carbon surface, but also introduces different surface properties like hydrophilicity and more oxygen functionality. (2) The high specific surface area and the presence of surface defects on ND@G render it an ideal substrate for the supporting of active metal species, anchoring the species both at the boundary between the ND core and the graphitic shell, as well as on the carbon shell itself. The reactive defective sp 2 graphitic curved shell of ND@G facilitates strong interactions with metals, and effectively enhancing the dispersion and stability of metal active sites. In addition, the strong interaction enable control the electronic structure by forming chemical bond between metal atom and C/O/N atom on the surface of ND@G, and then further tune/tailor the catalytic activity and selectivity by geometric and electronic effects. Additionally, the curved surface of ND@G influences the electronic properties of active sites in electrochemical reactions, optimizing proton and electron transfer and improving reaction and diffusion rates in electrocatalysis. Yet, we must admit that how these electronic effects work on the metal species is still not clear. ND@G with a nanodiamond core and graphitic shell represents a distinctive category of nanocarbon materials in heterogeneous catalysis, as either a metal catalyst support or a metal-free catalyst. Their unique features are crucial for developing catalysts with superior activity performance. Enhanced knowledge of these features, which are often underestimated, will lead to novel and innovative applications. Despite recent progress in employing ND@G in various reactions, both as a support or catalyst, as well as the growing understanding about the correlation between its structure and catalytic performance, there are still unresolved issues: Due to the complex and dynamic evolution of the complicated carbon surface chemistry during the reaction, there is still debate over the definitive active sites in various catalytic processes when ND@G was used as metal-free catalyst. Model carbon catalysts with specific single species, such as functional groups, zigzag and armchair configurations, have been used to identify the active sites in some reactions. Sophisticated in situ/operando methodologies (XPS, XAS, etc.) are essential to get more information. Unfortunately, it is still difficult to undisputedly figure out the reason why it always shows different behavior than other carbons. In addition, ND@G, as a metal-free catalyst, faces challenges in activating H2 molecules during hydrogenation reactions. It has been noted that frustrated Lewis pairs can activate H2 molecules, hence further research is needed to determine how to effectively establish frustrated Lewis pairs on the ND@G surface. Another neglected point is the C–H bond, which is generally considered inert during reactions and could be an active agent during reactions. It is always misunderstood as a C–H bond on aromatic structure. The Π electron network on the neighboring graphitic structure definitely brings totally different effects on it. Like carbon as a metal-free catalyst was quite unbelievable many years before, can the C–H bond on the carbon surface be the active site for many reactions? Our answer is YES! For the modification with heteroatoms doping, most mechanisms remain speculative, and there is no consensus on their operational mechanism. Further systematic investigation is needed to clarify the precise effects of heteroatom precursors, mass fractions, and heteroatom structure on catalytic activity and stability. For the ND@G-supported metal species, presently, the loading amount of metal is minimal when metals are dispersed on ND@G in the form of AMDs. The strategies to increase the loading amount of metal, without altering the dispersion of metal species should be developed by optimizing preparation methods or introducing more defect sites on the graphitic shell. The interlayer properties, especially with those defective structures on the top layer while perfect graphitic structures on the bottom layer, should be paid more attention. The interface between the sp 2 and sp 3 layers could be more interesting with more special properties. While introducing heteroatoms, more layers and amorphous carbon islands can also be introduced. Additionally, the interaction between ND@G support and metal species, especially for atomically dispersed active sites, is most currently speculative through theoretical predictions and computational modeling. It is essential to consider how to accurately determine the interaction mechanisms between the ND@G support and metal species. One truth is there are many different defects on the carbon surface, metal species on different defects should have different properties and their neighboring defects also contribute to their properties. Considering these points, there are countless active species on the carbon surface. How to distinguish them is the main challenge. Before that, figuring out the defective structures is necessary. However, the majority of current studies depend on Raman spectroscopy to detect the presence of defects within ND@G structures. There is a need for the development of advanced characterization techniques to probe into specific types of surface defects. Some molecular agents can be used to detect different functional groups. As mentioned above, the C–H bond at the edge might also be titrated by some special reaction. Thermal stability of different oxygen functional groups is big enough to distinguish them, which could also be a key for understanding C–H bond, as the thermal stability of C–H bond at different defective structures are also different. Electrochemical reduction and oxidation of these specific defective structures can also provide some information for understanding the basic surface chemistry. The most important thing is to be careful to give any specific conclusion without fully considering the whole carbon surface chemistry. Liyun Zhang obtained her Ph.D. at the Institute of Metal Research (IMR), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) in 2016, and then joined the IMR, CAS as an assistant researcher. Now, she is an associate professor at Qufu Normal University. Her research interests lie in the investigation of the structure-performance relationship of supported metal catalysts in heterogeneous catalysis. Kang Gao received his BSc (2014) and MSc (2017) degrees from the Hebei University of Engineering and performed a Ph.D. majoring in chemical engineering at Université Laval (Quebec, Canada). His research interests are heterogeneous catalysis, bifunctional materials, valorization of residues, biomass conversion, and CO2 capture and utilization, as well as a particular focus on synthesis and applications of carbon-based materials. Chaoan Liang received his bachelor's degree from Longdong University and his master's degree from Changchun University of Technology. He then worked as an assistant engineer at Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His research interests include controlled preparation and application of nanocarbon-based materials in heterogeneous catalysis, carbon surface catalysis and CO2 conversion and utilization. Guangjing Feng graduated from Qufu Normal University with a bachelor's degree and is now a direct doctoral student of the Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Her research interests include the design, synthesis and application of olefin allomerization catalysts, as well as the research of reaction mechanisms. Jiali Sun received her Ph.D. in metallurgy in 2023 from Northeastern University. She then moved to the Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences as an assistant researcher. Her research interests lie in the synthesis and modification of carbon materials, with a focus on the investigation of structure-property correlations, as well as biochar application in the comprehensive utilization of metallurgical solid waste. Peng Zhang obtained his PhD majoring in chemical engineering from Xi’an Jiaotong University in 2021 and now works as a research associate at Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His research is mainly focused on the rational design of functional carbon surfaces and its applications in heterogeneous catalysis, specifically targeting the capture and transformation of CO2 as C1 resources. Yuxiao Ding received his Ph.D. from the Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences (China) in 2015. Afterward, he joined the Max Planck Institute for Chemical Energy Conversion (Germany) as a postdoc researcher and started a new research team in 2021 at the Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics. His research interests focus on carbon surface chemistry and related applications in catalysis and energy-associated areas.

coredata.dc:description: Developing innovative catalysts continues to be a pivotal interest within the heterogeneous catalysis area. The carbonaceous material ND@G, featuring a sp 2/sp 3 hybrid architecture, comprises a nanodiamond (ND) core structure encased within an ultrathin graphitic nanoshell (G), and has been widely exploited as a metal-free catalyst or a support for metal catalyst. Its unique curved zero-dimensional structure/surface and tunable defective surface characteristics endow it with outstanding performance in different heterogeneous catalytic systems. The present review summarized the construction of the diverse types of ND@G and a wide-ranging valorization of structure–activity relation with its catalytic mechanism in various reactions. The recent advancements in the impact of active sites’ architecture and the interaction between metal and support (preventing the as-formed metal species migration and agglomeration based on ND@G) on the catalytic performance of supported metal catalysts are particularly highlighted. The current challenges and outlooks/opportunities confronted by ND@G materials in catalysis are prospected by virtue of its fundamental physicochemical characterizations and potential catalytic estimation. This in-depth analysis seeks to pave the way for effective utilizing the ND@G in catalytic processes. Based on our knowledge, we also identify the challenges along with this area and offer some perspectives on how to overcome them.
